Environment Agency|access-date=2018-06-19|language=en}}</ref> |0.00215 |465.12<ref name=":14" /> |}
== Land transport means == === Walking === [[File:Nordic Walkers near Ilkley 020.JPG|thumb|[[Nordic walking|Nordic walkers]]]] A {{convert|68|kg|abbr=on}} person walking at {{convert|4|km/h|abbr=on}} requires approximately {{convert|210|kcal}} of [[food energy]] per hour, which is equivalent to 4.55 km/MJ.<ref name="brianmac">{{cite web|url=http://www.brianmac.demon.co.uk/energyexp.htm|title=Energy expenditure for walking and running|first=Brian|last=Mackenzie|publisher=}}</ref> {{convert|1|USgal|L|abbr=on}} of gasoline contains about {{convert|114000|BTU|MJ|lk=in}}<ref name="EPA">{{cite web |title=Appendix B, Transportation Energy Data Book |year=2007 |author=EPA |url=http://www.epa.gov/oms/rfgecon.htm |accessdate=16 November 2010}}</ref> of energy, so this is approximately equivalent to {{convert|360|mpgus|L/100 km}}.
=== Velomobile === {{Main|Velomobile}} Velomobiles have the highest energy efficiency of any known mode of personal transport because of their small frontal area and aerodynamic shape. At a speed of {{convert|50|km/h|abbr=on}}, the velomobile manufacturer WAW claims that only 0.5 kW·h (1.8 MJ) of energy per 100 km is needed to transport the passenger (= 18 J/m). This is around {{frac|1|5}} (20%) of what is needed to power a standard upright bicycle without aerodynamic cladding at same speed, and {{frac|1|50}} (2%) of that which is consumed by an average fossil fuel or electric car (the velomobile efficiency corresponds to 4700 miles per US gallon, 2000 km/L, or 0.05 L/100 km)<ref name=":3" />. Real energy from food used by human is 4-5 times more<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://gearandgrit.com/convert-watts-calories-burned-cycling/|title=How to Convert Watts to Calories Burned While Cycling – Gear & Grit.|last=|first=|date=2017-01-06|work=Gear & Grit|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref>. Unfortunately their energy use advantage over bicycles is smaller with decrease of speed and disappear at around 10 km/h where power needed for velomobile and triathlon bike is almost the same<ref name=":22">{{cite web|url=http://www.kreuzotter.de/english/espeed.htm|title=Power vs speed calculator|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Bicycle === [[File:Left side of Flying Pigeon.jpg|thumb|A Chinese [[Flying Pigeon]] bicycle]] A standard lightweight, moderate-speed bicycle is one of the most energy-efficient forms of transport. Compared with walking, a {{convert|140|lb|abbr=on|order=flip}} cyclist riding at {{convert|16|km/h|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} requires about half the food energy per unit distance: 27 kcal/km, {{convert|3.1|kW·h|abbr=on}} per 100 km, or 43 kcal/mi.<!--43 kcal/mi is 3.10533705 kWh / (100 km) --><ref name=brianmac /><!-- this is not an original reference – just a table --> This converts to about {{convert|732|mpgus|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Wolfram Alpha">{{cite web |title=Calculation of conversion from dietary calories per mile to miles per gallon gasoline, using the energy density of gasoline listed by Wolfram Alpha| year=2011|url=http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=%2843+calories%2Fmile+in+megajoules%2Fmile+%2F+34.8+megajoules%2Fliter+in+gallons%29^-1&a=UnitClash_*calories.*LargeCalories--&a=UnitClash_*gallons.*Gallons.dflt--#|accessdate=19 Jul 2011}}</ref><!-- Simple calculation to convert dietary calories per mile to miles per US gallon --> This means that a bicycle will use between 10-25 times less energy per distance traveled than a personal car, depending on fuel source and size of the car. This figure does depend on the speed and mass of the rider: greater speeds give higher air drag and heavier riders consume more energy per unit distance. In addition, because bicycles are very lightweight (usually between 7–15 kg) this means they consume very low amounts of materials and energy to manufacture. In comparison to an automobile weighing 1500 kg or more, a bicycle typically requires 100-200 times less energy to produce than an automobile.
=== Motorized bicycle === A motorized bicycle allows human power and the assistance of a {{convert|49|cm3|abbr=on}} engine, giving a range of {{convert|160|to(-)|200|mpgus|abbr=on}}.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} Electric pedal-assisted bikes run on as little as {{convert|1.0|kW·h|abbr=on}} per 100 km,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ebikes.ca/documents/Ebike_Energy.pdf|title=The Energy Cost of Electric and Human-Powered Bicycles|last=Lemire-Elmore|first=Justin|date=13 April 2004|website=ebikes.ca|access-date=}}</ref> while maintaining speeds in excess of {{convert|30|km/h|abbr=on}}.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} These best-case figures rely on a human doing 70% of the work, with around {{convert|3.6|MJ|kW·h|abbr=on}} per 100 km coming from the motor. This makes an electric bicycle one of the most efficient possible motorized vehicles, behind only a motorized velomobile.
=== Electric kick scooter === [[File:Bird scooters on the sidewalk in San Jose.jpg|thumb|Electric kick scooters, part of a [[scooter-sharing system]], in San Jose, California.]] Electric kick scooters, such as those used by scooter-sharing systems like [[Bird (company)|Bird]] or [[Lime (transportation company)|Lime]], typically have a maximum range of under {{convert|30|km|mi|abbr=on}} and a maximum speed of roughly {{convert|15.5|mph|kph|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Xiaomi M365"/> Intended to fit into a [[last mile (transportation)|last mile]] niche and be ridden in bike lanes, they require little skill from the rider. Because of their light weight and small motors, they're extremely energy-efficient.
=== Human power === To be thorough, a comparison must also consider the energy costs of producing, transporting and packaging of fuel (food or fossil fuel), the energy incurred in disposing of exhaust waste, and the energy costs of manufacturing the vehicle. This last can be significant given that walking requires little or no special equipment, while automobiles, for example, require a great deal of energy to produce and have relatively short lifespans. In addition, any comparison of electric vehicles and liquid-fuelled vehicles must include the fuel consumed in the power station to generate the electricity. In the UK for instance the efficiency of the electricity generation and distribution system is around 0.40{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}.
=== Automobiles === {{Main|Fuel economy in automobiles}} {{See also|Fuel economy-maximizing behaviors}} [[File:Bugatti Veyron 16.4 – Frontansicht (3), 5. April 2012, Düsseldorf.jpg|thumb|Bugatti Veyron]] The automobile is an inefficient vehicle compared to other modes of transport. This is because the ratio between the mass of the vehicle and the mass of the passengers is much higher when compared to other modes of transport.
Automobile [[fuel efficiency]] is most commonly expressed in terms of the volume of fuel consumed per one hundred kilometres (L/100 km), but in some countries (including the United States, the United Kingdom and India) it is more commonly expressed in terms of the distance per volume fuel consumed (km/L or [[miles per gallon]]). This is complicated by the different energy content of fuels such as petrol and diesel. The [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] (ORNL) states that the energy content of unleaded gasoline is 115,000 British thermal unit (BTU) per US gallon (32 MJ/L) compared to 130,500 BTU per US gallon (36.4 MJ/L) for diesel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bioenergy.ornl.gov/papers/misc/energy_conv.html |title=Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927181836/http://bioenergy.ornl.gov/papers/misc/energy_conv.html |archivedate=27 September 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
A second important consideration is the energy costs of producing energy. Bio-fuels, [[electricity]] and [[hydrogen]], for instance, have significant energy inputs in their production. [[Hydrogen production]] efficiency are 50-70% when produced from natural gas, and 10-15% from electricity.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} The efficiency of hydrogen production, as well as the energy required to store and transport hydrogen, must to be combined with the vehicle efficiency to yield net efficiency.<ref name="eere">{{cite web|url=http://www1.eere.energy.gov/vehiclesandfuels/avta/pdfs/hicev/sae_hydrogen_presentation_2006.pdf|title=Vehicle Technologies Office - Department of Energy|publisher=}}</ref> Because of this, hydrogen automobiles are one of the least efficient means of passenger transport, generally around 50 times as much energy must be put into the production of hydrogen compared to how much is used to move the car.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
A third consideration to take into account when calculating energy efficiency of automobiles is the occupancy rate of the vehicle. Although the consumption per unit distance per vehicle increases with increasing number of passengers, this increase is slight compared to the reduction in consumption per unit distance per passenger. This means that higher occupancy yields higher energy efficiency per passenger. Automobile occupancy varies across regions. For example, the estimated average occupancy rate is about 1.3 passengers per car in the San Francisco Bay Area,<ref>[http://www.mtc.ca.gov/maps_and_data/datamart/forecast/ass98_tab8.htm Maps and Data] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070612201154/http://www.mtc.ca.gov/maps_and_data/datamart/forecast/ass98_tab8.htm |date=12 June 2007 }} – Metropolitan Transportation Commission for the nine-county San Francisco Bay Area, California</ref> while the 2006 UK estimated average is 1.58.<ref name="ukdft_carocc">{{cite web |title=Transport trends: current edition |date=8 January 2008 |publisher=UK [[Department for Transport]] |url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/statistics/datatablespublications/trends/current/ |accessdate=23 March 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080422035124/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/statistics/datatablespublications/trends/current/ |archivedate=22 April 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Fourth, the energy needed to build and maintain roads is an important consideration, as is the [[energy returned on energy invested]] (EROEI). Between these two factors, roughly 20% must be added to the energy of the fuel consumed, to accurately account for the total energy used.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
Finally, vehicle energy efficiency calculations would be misleading without factoring the energy cost of producing the vehicle itself. This initial energy cost can of course be depreciated over the life of the vehicle to calculate an average energy efficiency over its effective life span. In other words, vehicles that take a lot of energy to produce and are used for relatively short periods will require a great deal more energy over their effective lifespan than those that do not, and are therefore much less energy efficient than they may otherwise seem. Hybrid and electric cars use less energy in their operation than comparable petroleum-fueled cars but more energy is used to manufacture them, so the overall difference would be less than immediately apparent. Compare, for example, walking, which requires no special equipment at all, and an automobile, produced in and shipped from another country, and made from parts manufactured around the world from raw materials and minerals mined and processed elsewhere again, and used for a limited number of years. According to the French energy and environment agency ADEME,<ref>(fr) [http://www.ademe.fr/sites/default/files/assets/documents/90511_acv-comparative-ve-vt-resume.pdf Life cycle assessment] [http://citenpl.internal.epo.org/wf/web/citenpl/citenpl.html?_url=http%3A//www.ademe.fr/sites/default/files/assets/documents/90511_acv-comparative-ve-vt-resume.pdf CiteNPL<span class="doc">DOCS</span>] website www.ademe.fr see page 9</ref> an average motor car has an embodied energy content of 20,800 kWh and an average electric vehicle amounts to 34,700 kWh. The electric car requires nearly twice as much energy to produce, primarily due to the large amount of mining and purification necessary for the rare earth metals and other materials used in lithium-ion batteries and in the electric drive motors. This represents a significant portion of the energy used over the life of the car (in some cases nearly as much as energy that is used through the fuel that is consumed, effectively doubling the car's per-distance energy consumption), and cannot be ignored when comparing automobiles to other transport modes. It is important to note, also, that as these are average numbers for French automobiles and they are likely to be significantly larger in more auto-centric countries like the United States and Canada, where much larger and heavier cars are more common.
Driving practices and vehicles can be modified to improve their energy efficiency by about 15%.<ref name="Beusen">{{cite journal |author=Beusen|title=Using on-board logging devices to study the long-term impact of an eco-driving course |journal=Transportation Research D |volume=14 |issue= |pages=514–520 |year=2009 |pmid= |doi= |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/231614817_Using_on-board_logging_devices_to_study_the_long-term_impact_of_an_eco-driving_course?ev=prf_pub|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="transport">{{cite web|url=http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/transport/speed-limits|title=Do lower speed limits on motorways reduce fuel consumption and pollutant emissions? |accessdate=2013-08-12}}</ref>
On a percentage basis, if there is one occupant in an automobile, between 0.4-0.6% of the total energy used is used to move the person in the car, while 99.4-99.6% (about 165 to 250 times more) is used to move the car.
==== Example consumption figures ==== [[File:Solar Vehicles - Winnipeg.jpg|thumb|Two American solar cars in Canada]] * [[Solar car]]s use no externally supplied fuel other than sunlight, charging the batteries entirely from built-in solar panels, and typically use less than 3 kW·h per 100 miles (67 kJ/km or 1.86 kW·h/100 km). These cars are not designed for passenger or utility use and would not be practical as such due to speed, payload, and inherent design.<ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/autopia/2009/02/hot-wheels-mi/|title=MIT Unveils 90 MPH Solar Race Car|publisher=}}</ref> * The four passenger [[Global Electric Motorcars|GEM]] [[Neighborhood electric vehicle|NER]] uses {{convert|169|Wh/mile|mpge+kWh/100 km|abbr=on}},<ref name=":5">{{cite web|url=http://www1.eere.energy.gov/vehiclesandfuels/avta/pdfs/nev/gem2005e4.pdf|title=Vehicle Technologies Office - Department of Energy|publisher=}}</ref> which equates to 2.6 kW·h/100 km per person when fully occupied<!--867 passenger-miles/gal (0.27 L/100 km)-->, albeit at only {{convert|24|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. * The General Motors EV1 was rated in a test with a charging efficiency of 373 Wh-AC/mile or 23 kWh/100 km<!--168 W·h/mile at 60 mph or, at 125,000 Btu/gal 218 mpg (1 l/100 km) or 436 passenger-miles/gal (0.63 l/100 km)--><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.eere.energy.gov/vehiclesandfuels/avta/pdfs/fsev/eva_results/ev1_eva.pdf|title=Vehicle Technologies Office - Department of Energy|publisher=}}</ref> approximately equivalent to {{convert|2.6|L/100km|abbr=on}} for petroleum-fuelled vehicles. * Chevrolet Volt in full electric mode uses {{convert|36|kWh/100 mi|kJ/km mpge}}, meaning it may approach or exceed the energy efficiency of walking if the car is fully occupied with 4 or more passengers, although the relative emissions produced may not follow the same trends if analyzing environmental impacts. * The Daihatsu Charade 993cc turbo diesel (1987–1993) won the most fuel efficient vehicle award for going round the United Kingdom consuming an average of {{convert|100|mpgimp|L/100km|order=flip|abbr=on|sigfig=3}}. It was surpassed only recently by the VW Lupo 3 L which consumes about {{convert|102|mpgimp|L/100km|order=flip|abbr=on|sigfig=3}}. Both cars are rare to find on the popular market. The Daihatsu had major problems with rust and structural safety which contributes to its rarity and the quite short production run. * The [[Volkswagen Polo 1.4 TDI Bluemotion]] and the SEAT Ibiza 1.4 === Trains === Trains are in general one of the most efficient means of transport for freight and passengers. Efficiency varies significantly with passenger loads, and losses incurred in electricity generation and supply (for electrified systems),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lafn.org/~dave/trans/energy/fuel-eff-20th-3.html#japan_|title=Fuel-Efficiency of Travel in the 20th Century: Appendix-Notes|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.lafn.org/~dave/trans/energy/fuel-eff-20th-2.html#_japan Fuel Efficiency of Travel in the 20th Century])</ref> and, importantly, end-to-end delivery, where stations are not the originating final destinations of a journey.
Actual consumption depends on gradients, maximum speeds, and loading and stopping patterns. Data produced for the European MEET project (Methodologies for Estimating Air Pollutant Emissions) illustrate the different consumption patterns over several track sections. The results show the consumption for a German ICE high-speed train varied from around {{convert|19|to(-)|33|kWh/km|abbr=on}}. The data also reflects the weight of the train per passenger. For example, [[TGV]] double-deck Duplex trains use lightweight materials, which keep axle loads down and reduce damage to track and also save energy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cfit.gov.uk/docs/2001/racomp/racomp/a1.htm|title=Commission for integrated transport, Short haul air v High speed rail|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426112620/http://www.cfit.gov.uk/docs/2001/racomp/racomp/a1.htm|archivedate=26 April 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The specific energy consumption of the trains worldwide amounts to about 150 kJ/pkm and 150 kJ/tkm (i.e. 4,2 kWh/100 pkm and 4,2 kWh/100 tkm) in terms of final energy. Passenger transportation by rail requires less than one-tenth of the energy needed to move a person by car or plane. This is the reason why, although accounting for 9% of world passenger transportation activity (expressed in pkm) in 2015, rail passenger services represented only 1% of final energy demand in passenger transportation.<ref>[https://uic.org/IMG/pdf/handbook_iea-uic_2017_web3.pdf Railway handbook: Energy consumption and {{CO2}} emissions] website of the [[International Union of Railways]] (UIC, based in [[Paris]]); see figure 15 on page 27, and values on page 86. This document is the result of a joint work between UIC and [[International Energy Agency]] (IEA, based in [[Paris]])</ref>

==== Braking losses ==== Stopping is a considerable source of inefficiency. Modern electric trains like the ''[[Shinkansen]]'' (the ''Bullet Train'') use [[regenerative braking]] to return current into the [[overhead lines|catenary]] while they brake. A Siemens study indicated that regenerative braking might recover 41.6% of the total energy consumed. The Passenger Rail (Urban and Intercity) and Scheduled Intercity and All Charter Bus Industries Technological and Operational Improvements – FINAL REPORT states that "Commuter operations can dissipate more than half of their total traction energy in braking for stops." and that "We estimate [[head-end power]] to be 35 percent (but it could possibly be as high as 45 percent) of total energy consumed by commuter railways."<ref>[http://www.tc.gc.ca/programs/environment/climatechange/subgroups1/Main_Table/study1/Final_Report/Final_Report.htm#_Toc474834390 Bus and Rail Final Report]{{dead link|date=June 2018}}</ref> Having to accelerate and decelerate a heavy train load of people at every stop is inefficient despite regenerative braking which can recover typically around 20% of the energy wasted in braking. Weight is a determinant of braking losses.
=== Buses === [[File:Mettis BRT Metz.jpg|thumb|The [[Bus Rapid Transit]] of [[Metz]] uses a [[Hybrid vehicle|diesel-electric hybrid]] driving system, developed by Belgian [[Van Hool]] manufacturer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanhool.be/ENG/highlights/vanhoolpresentst.html|title=Van Hool presents the ExquiCity Design Mettis.|date=|accessdate=5 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605074801/http://www.vanhool.be/ENG/highlights/vanhoolpresentst.html|archivedate=5 June 2013|df=dmy}}</ref>]] * In July 2005, the average occupancy for buses in the UK was stated to be 9 passengers per vehicle.<ref name=":11">{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200506/cmhansrd/vo050720/text/50720w26.htm#50720w26.html_sbhd1|title=Passenger Transport (Fuel Consumption)|date=2005-07-20|publisher=UK House of Commons|work=Hansard|accessdate=2008-03-25}}</ref> * The fleet of 244 {{convert|40|ft|m|adj=on}} 1982 [[New Flyer]] [[trolley bus]]es in local service with [[BC Transit]] in Vancouver, Canada, in 1994/95 used 35,454,170 kWh for 12,966,285 vehicle km, or 9.84 MJ/vehicle km. Exact ridership on trolleybuses is not known, but with all 34 seats filled this equates to 0.32 MJ/passenger km. It is quite common to see people standing on Vancouver trolleybuses. This is a service with many stops per kilometre; part of the reason for the efficiency is the use of regenerative braking. * A commuter service in [[Santa Barbara, California]], USA, found average diesel bus efficiency of {{convert|6.0|mpgus|abbr=on}} (using [[Motor Coach Industries|MCI]] 102DL3 buses). With all 55 seats filled this equates to 330 passenger mpg; with 70% filled, 231 passenger mpg.<ref name=":10">{{cite web|url=https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy00osti/26758.pdf|title=Demonstration of Caterpillar C-10 Duel-Fuel Engines in MCI 102DL3 Commuter Buses | publisher=National Renewable Energy Laboratory | date=January 2000 | accessdate=5 September 2018}}</ref> * In 2011 the fleet of 752 buses in the city of [[Lisbon]] had an average speed of 14.4 km/h and an average occupancy of 20.1 passengers per vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.carris.pt/pt/indicadores-de-atividade/|title=Indicadores de Atividade|last=Seara.com|first=|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Other === * [[NASA]]'s [[Crawler-Transporter]] is used to move the Shuttle from storage to the launch pad. It uses diesel and has one of the highest fuel consumption rates on record, {{convert|150|USgal/mi}}<!-- which is 32 feet/gallon-->.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/facilities/crawler.html|title=Crawler-Transporter System|publisher=}}</ref>
== Air transport means ==
=== Aircraft === {{Main|Fuel economy in aircraft|Environmental impact of aviation}} [[File:Solar Impulse SI2 pilote Bertrand Piccard Payerne November 2014.jpg|thumb|[[Solar Impulse]] 2, a [[solar aircraft]]]]
A principal determinant of energy consumption in aircraft is [[Drag (physics)|drag]], which must be opposed by thrust for the aircraft to progress. * [[Induced drag|Drag]] is proportional to the [[lift (force)|lift]] required for flight,<ref name=Capehart>Barney L. Capehart (2007). ''Encyclopedia of Energy Engineering and Technology'', Volume 1. CRC Press. {{ISBN|0-8493-3653-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8493-3653-9}}.</ref> which is equal to the weight of the aircraft. As induced drag increases with weight, mass reduction, with improvements in engine efficiency and reductions in [[aerodynamic drag]], has been a principal source of efficiency gains in aircraft, with a rule-of-thumb being that a 1% weight reduction corresponds to around a 0.75% reduction in fuel consumption.<ref name=Capehart /> * Flight altitude affects engine efficiency. Jet-engine efficiency increases at altitude up to the [[tropopause]], the temperature minimum of the atmosphere; at lower temperatures, the [[Carnot efficiency]] is higher.<ref name=Capehart /> Jet engine efficiency is also increased at high speeds, but above about Mach 0.85 the airframe aerodynamic losses increase faster. * Compressibility effects: beginning at [[transonic]] speeds of around Mach 0.85, shockwaves form increasing drag. * For supersonic flight, it is difficult to achieve a [[lift to drag ratio]] greater than 5, and fuel consumption is increased in proportion.
{| class="infobox bordered" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" |+ ''Concorde'' [[fuel efficiency]] comparison (assuming jets are filled to capacity) ! Aircraft  !style="width:6em"| Concorde<ref name = 'powerplant'>[http://www.concordesst.com/powerplant.html "Powerplant."] ''concordesst.com''. Retrieved: 2 December 2009.</ref> !style="width:6em"| [[Boeing 747]]-400<ref>{{cite web |url = http://boeing.com/commercial/747family/pf/pf_400_prod.html |title = Technical Specifications: Boeing 747-400 |publisher = ''Boeing'' |accessdate = 11 January 2010}}</ref><!-- 216,840 litres at 13,450 km maximum range with 524 passengers ---> |- | Passenger-miles/imperial gallon | style="text-align:center;"| 17 || style="text-align:center;"| 109 |- | Passenger-miles/US gallon | style="text-align:center;"| 14 || style="text-align:center;"| 91 |- | Litres/100 passenger-km | style="text-align:center;"| 16.6|| style="text-align:center;"| 3.1 |}
Passenger airplanes averaged 4.8 l/100 km per passenger (1.4 MJ/passenger-km) (49 passenger-miles per gallon) in 1998.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} Note that on average 20% of seats are left unoccupied. Jet aircraft efficiencies are improving: Between 1960 and 2000 there was a 55% overall fuel efficiency gain (if one were to exclude the inefficient and limited fleet of the DH Comet 4 and to consider the Boeing 707 as the base case).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transportenvironment.org/docs/Publications/2005pubs/2005-12_nlr_aviation_fuel_efficiency.pdf|title=National Aerospace Laboratory] [http://citenpl.internal.epo.org/wf/web/citenpl/citenpl.html?_url=http%3A//www.transportenvironment.org/docs/Publications/2005pubs/2005-12_nlr_aviation_fuel_efficiency.pdf CiteNPL<span class="doc">DOCS</span>|website=transportenvironment.org}}</ref> Most of the improvements in efficiency were gained in the first decade when jet craft first came into widespread commercial use. Compared to advanced piston engine airliners of the 1950s, current jet airliners are only marginally more efficient per passenger-mile.<ref>Peeters P.M., Middel J., Hoolhorst A. (2005). [http://www.transportenvironment.org/sites/te/files/media/2005-12_nlr_aviation_fuel_efficiency.pdf Fuel efficiency of commercial aircraft An overview of historical and future trends] [http://citenpl.internal.epo.org/wf/web/citenpl/citenpl.html?_url=http%3A//www.transportenvironment.org/sites/te/files/media/2005-12_nlr_aviation_fuel_efficiency.pdf CiteNPL<span class="doc">DOCS</span>]. National Aerospace Laboratory, The Netherlands.</ref> Between 1971 and 1998 the fleet-average annual improvement per available seat-kilometre was estimated at 2.4%. [[Concorde]] the [[supersonic transport]] managed about 17 passenger-miles to the Imperial gallon; similar to a business jet, but much worse than a subsonic turbofan aircraft. [[Airbus]] puts the fuel rate consumption of their [[Airbus A380|A380]] at less than 3 l/100 km per passenger (78 passenger-miles per US gallon).<ref>{{cite web|title=The A380: The future of flying |publisher=Airbus |url=http://www.airbus.com/en/myairbus/airbusview/the_a380_the_future_of_flying.html |accessdate=2008-03-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214144443/http://www.airbus.com/en/myairbus/airbusview/the_a380_the_future_of_flying.html |archivedate=14 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
[[File:Air France Airbus A380-800 F-HPJB.jpg|thumb|Air France Airbus A380-800]] The mass of an aircraft can be reduced by using light-weight materials such as [[titanium]], [[carbon fiber]] and other composite plastics. Expensive materials may be used, if the reduction of mass justifies the price of materials through improved fuel efficiency. The improvements achieved in fuel efficiency by mass reduction, reduces the amount of fuel that needs to be carried. This further reduces the mass of the aircraft and therefore enables further gains in fuel efficiency. For example, the Airbus A380 design includes multiple light-weight materials.
Airbus has showcased [[wingtip device]]s (sharklets or winglets) that can achieve 3.5 percent reduction in fuel consumption.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10609695|title='Shark fin' wings give airline chiefs something to smile about|first=Grant|last=Bradley|date=17 November 2009|publisher=|via=New Zealand Herald}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ylcrafts.com/en/newsInfo_51.shtml|title=A320 plane shark fins small winglets successfully completed the first flight test|publisher=}}</ref> There are wingtip devices on the Airbus A380. Further developed Minix winglets have been said to offer 6 percent reduction in fuel consumption.<ref name="gizmag">{{cite web|url=http://www.gizmag.com/minix-wing-tip-vortex-aircraft-aerodynamics/15526/|title=Minix wing tip device promises 6% gain in fuel efficiency for airliners|publisher=}}</ref> Winglets at the tip of an aircraft wing smooth out the wing-tip vortex (reducing the aircraft's wing drag) and can be retrofitted to any airplane.<ref name="gizmag" />
NASA and Boeing are conducting tests on a {{convert|500|lb|abbr=on}} "[[Blended wing body|blended wing]]" aircraft. This design allows for greater fuel efficiency since the whole craft produces lift, not just the wings.<ref>[http://www.ecogeek.org/content/view/871/ Ecogeek Article] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714133959/http://www.ecogeek.org/content/view/871/ |date=14 July 2014 }}</ref> The blended wing body (BWB) concept offers advantages in structural, aerodynamic and operating efficiencies over today's more conventional fuselage-and-wing designs. These features translate into greater range, fuel economy, reliability and life cycle savings, as well as lower manufacturing costs.<ref>[http://www.boeing.com/news/releases/2006/q4/061027b_nr.html "Boeing to Begin Ground Testing of X-48B Blended Wing Body Concept."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819141321/http://www.boeing.com/news/releases/2006/q4/061027b_nr.html |date=19 August 2012 }} ''Boeing'', 27 October 2006. Retrieved: 10 April 2012.</ref><ref>Lorenz III, Phillip. [http://www.arnold.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123059396 "AEDC testing brings unique blended wing aircraft closer to flight."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714223640/http://www.arnold.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123059396 |date=14 July 2014 }} ''AEDC, U.S. Air Force'', 3 July 2007. Retrieved: 10 April 2012.</ref> NASA has created a cruise efficient STOL (CESTOL) concept.
Fraunhofer Institute for Manufacturing Engineering and Applied Materials Research (IFAM) have researched a [[shark]] skin imitating paint that would reduce drag through a riblet effect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smartplanet.com/blog/intelligent-energy/a-sharkskin-coating-for-ships-planes-and-blades/1289|title=A sharkskin coating for ships, planes and blades - ZDNet|first=Melissa|last=Mahony|publisher=}}</ref> Aircraft are a major potential application for new technologies such as aluminium [[metal foam]] and [[nanotechnology]] such as the shark skin imitating paint.
[[Propfan]] propulsors are a more fuel efficient technology than [[jet engine|jets]] or [[turboprop]]s, but turboprops have an optimum speed below about 450 mph (700 km/h).<ref>{{cite web | last = Spakovszky | first = Zoltan | title = Unified Propulsion Lecture 1 | work = Unified Engineering Lecture Notes | publisher = MIT | year = 2009 | url = http://web.mit.edu/16.unified/www/SPRING/propulsion/UnifiedPropulsion3/UnifiedPropulsion3.htm | accessdate = 2009-04-03}}</ref> This speed is less than used with jets by major airlines today. However, the decrease in speed reduces drag. With the current {{Update after|2010|11|13}} high price for [[jet fuel]] and the emphasis on engine/airframe efficiency to reduce emissions, there is renewed interest in the propfan concept for jetliners that might come into service beyond the [[Boeing 787]] and [[Airbus A350]]XWB. For instance, Airbus has patented aircraft designs with twin rear-mounted counter-rotating propfans.<ref>{{Ref patent | country = US | number = 2009020643 | status = application | title = Aircraft having reduced environmental impact | pubdate = 2009-01-22 | inventor = Airbus | invent1 = Pierre-Emmanuel Gall | invent2 = Christophe Cros | class = B64D27/00 }}</ref> NASA has conducted an Advanced Turboprop Project (ATP), where they researched a variable pitch propfan that produced less noise and achieved high speeds.
Related to fuel efficiency is the [[Environmental impact of aviation|impact of aviation emissions on climate]].
==== Small aircraft ==== [[File:Dyn'Aero MCR-4S, Private JP6251860.jpg|thumb|Dyn'Aéro MCR4S]] * Motor-gliders made of composite materials can reach an extremely low fuel consumption for cross-country flights, using thermal air currents and winds. * At 160 km/h, a diesel powered two-seater Dieselis burns 6 liters of fuel per hour, 1.9 liters per 100 passenger km.<ref>Contact, Experimental Aircraft and Powerplant Newsforum for Designers and Builders, Issue 55, March–April 2000</ref> * at 220 km/h, a four-seater 100 hp [[Dyn'Aéro MCR4S|MCR-4S]] burns 20 liters of gas per hour, 2.2 liters per 100 passenger km. * Under continuous motorised flight at 225 km/h, a Pipistrel Sinus burns 11 liters of fuel per flight hour. Carrying 2 people aboard, it operates at 2.4 liters per 100 passenger km. * Ultralight aircraft Tecnam P92 Echo Classic at cruise speed of 185 km/h burns 17 liters of fuel per flight hour, 4.6 liters per 100 passenger km (2 people).<ref>{{cite web |title=Tecnam P92 Echo Classic |publisher=Tecnam costruzioni aeronautiche s.r.l. |url=http://www.tecnam.com/it-IT/flotta/ULTRALIGHT/p92-classic.aspx |accessdate=22 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529164518/http://www.tecnam.com/it-IT/flotta/ULTRALIGHT/p92-classic.aspx |archivedate=29 May 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Other modern ultralight aircraft have increased efficiency; Tecnam P2002 Sierra RG at cruise speed of 237 km/h burns 17 liters of fuel per flight hour, 3.6 liters per 100 passenger km (2 people).<ref>{{cite web |title=Tecnam P2002 Sierra De Luxe |publisher=Tecnam costruzioni aeronautiche s.r.l. |url=http://www.tecnam.com/it-IT/flotta/ULTRALIGHT/p2002-sierra-rg.aspx |accessdate=22 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608021156/http://www.tecnam.com/it-IT/flotta/ULTRALIGHT/p2002-sierra-rg.aspx |archivedate=8 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> * Two-seater and four-seater flying at 250 km/h with old generation engines can burn 25 to 40 liters per flight hour, 3 to 5 liters per 100 passenger km. * The [[Sikorsky S-76]]C++ twin turbine helicopter gets about {{convert|1.65|mpgus|abbr=on}} at {{convert|140|kn}} and carries 12 for about 19.8 passenger-miles per gallon (11.9 L per 100 passenger km).{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}
== Water transport means ==
=== Ships ===
==== Queen Elizabeth ==== [[File:QE2-South Queensferry.jpg|thumb|[[Queen Elizabeth 2]] ]] [[Cunard Line|Cunard]] stated that Queen Elizabeth 2 travelled 49.5 feet per imperial gallon of diesel oil (3.32 m/l or 41.2 ft/US gal), and that it had a passenger capacity of 1777.<ref>{{cite web|title=Queen Elizabeth 2: Technical Information |publisher=Cunard Line |url=http://www.cunard.com/uploads/QE2_Tech.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090318012344/http://www.cunard.com/uploads/QE2_Tech.pdf |archivedate=18 March 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> Thus carrying 1777 passengers we can calculate an efficiency of 16.7 passenger miles per imperial gallon (16.9 l/100 p·km or 13.9 p·mpg<sub>–US</sub>).
====Cruise ships==== {{MS|Oasis of the Seas}} has a capacity of 6,296 passengers and a fuel efficiency of 14.4 passenger miles per US gallon. [[Voyager-class cruise ship]]s have a capacity of 3,114 passengers and a fuel efficiency of 12.8 passenger miles per US gallon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brighthubengineering.com/naval-architecture/100758-cruise-ship-fuel-efficiency/|title=Cruise Ship Gas Mileage|publisher=}}</ref>
==== Emma Maersk ==== [[Emma Maersk]] uses a [[Wärtsilä-Sulzer RTA96-C]], which consumes 163 g/kW·h and 13,000 kg/h. If it carries 13,000 containers then 1 kg fuel transports one container for one hour over a distance of 45 km. The ship takes 18 days from Tanjung (Singapore) to Rotterdam (Netherlands), 11 from Tanjung to Suez, and 7 from Suez to Rotterdam,<ref>[http://www.emma-maersk.com/schedules/ Emma Mærsk schedules] ''Mærsk'', 5 December 2011.</ref> which is roughly 430 hours, and has 80 MW, +30 MW<!-- this needs clarification: 80 MW of what? This section seems incomplete. -->. 18 days at a mean speed of {{convert|25|kn|km/h}} gives a total distance of {{convert|10800|nmi|km}}.
Assuming the Emma Maersk consumes diesel (as opposed to fuel oil which would be the more precise fuel) then 1 kg diesel = 0.832 litres = 0.317 US gallons. This corresponds to 46,525 kJ. Assuming a standard 14 tonnes per container (per teu) this yields 74 kJ per tonne-km at a speed of 45 kmh (24 knots).
==== Sailboats ==== A [[sailboat]], much like a solar car, can locomote without consuming any fuel. A sail boat such as a Dinghy using just wind power requires no input energy in terms of fuel. However some manual energy is required by the crew to steer the boat and adjust the sails using lines. In addition energy will be needed for demands other than propulsion, such as cooking, heating or lighting. The fuel efficiency of a single-occupancy boat is highly dependent on the size of its engine, the speed at which it travels, and its displacement. Due to the high viscosity of water, with a single passenger, the equivalent energy efficiency will be lower than in a car, train, or plane.
== International transport comparisons ==
=== European Public transport === Rail and bus are generally required to serve 'off peak' and rural services, which by their nature have lower loads than city bus routes and inter city train lines. Moreover, due to their 'walk on' ticketing it is much harder to match daily demand and passenger numbers. As a consequence, the overall load factor on UK railways is 35% or 90 people per train:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atoc-comms.org/dynamic/publication.php?publication=6|title=ATOC|publisher=}}</ref>
Conversely, airline services generally work on point-to-point networks between large population centres and are 'pre-book' in nature. Using [[yield management]], overall load factors can be raised to around 70–90%. Intercity train operators have begun to use similar techniques, with loads reaching typically 71% overall for TGV services in France and a similar figure for the UK's [[Virgin Trains]] services.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/about/strategy/whitepapers/whitepapercm7176/|title=Delivering a sustainable railway - Publications - GOV.UK|publisher=}}</ref>
For emissions, the electricity generating source needs to be taken into account.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atoc-comms.org/admin/userfiles/Energy%20&%20Emissions%20Statement%20-%20web%20version.pdf|title=Energy & Emissions Statement}}</ref><!--[http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/business/envrp/pdf/passenger-transport.pdf (Bad link)] Below seems to be equivalent from the archives --><ref>[http://archive.defra.gov.uk/environment/business/reporting/pdf/passenger-transport.pdf Defra 2008 Guidelines to Defra’s GHG Conversion Factors] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120105065320/http://archive.defra.gov.uk/environment/business/reporting/pdf/passenger-transport.pdf |date=5 January 2012 }} [http://citenpl.internal.epo.org/wf/web/citenpl/citenpl.html?_url=http%3A//archive.defra.gov.uk/environment/business/reporting/pdf/passenger-transport.pdf CiteNPL<span class="doc">DOCS</span>] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120105065320/http://archive.defra.gov.uk/environment/business/reporting/pdf/passenger-transport.pdf |date=5 January 2012 }}[http://citenpl.internal.epo.org/wf/web/citenpl/citenpl.html?_url=https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20120105065320/http%3A//archive.defra.gov.uk/environment/business/reporting/pdf/passenger-transport.pdf CiteNPL<span class="doc">DOCS</span>]<span> 5 January 2012 at the </span>[[Wayback Machine]]<span>.</span> </ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aef.org.uk/downloads//Grams_CO2_transportmodesUK.pdf|title=Kilograms of CO2 per passenger kilometre for different modes of transport within the UK] [http://citenpl.internal.epo.org/wf/web/citenpl/citenpl.html?_url=http%3A//www.aef.org.uk/downloads//Grams_CO2_transportmodesUK.pdf CiteNPL<span class="doc">DOCS</span>|website=aef.org.uk}}</ref>

Average passengers<br />per vehicle ! BTU per <br />passenger-mile ! MJ per <br />passenger-kilometre |- | Rail (intercity [[Amtrak]]) | style="text-align:center;"| 20.9 | {{convert|2435|BTU/mi|MJ/km|3|disp=tablecen|sortable=on}} |- | Motorcycles | style="text-align:center;"| 1.16 | {{convert|2460|BTU/mi|MJ/km|disp=tablecen|sortable=on}} |- | Rail (transit light & heavy) | style="text-align:center;"| 24.5 | {{convert|2516|BTU/mi|MJ/km|disp=tablecen|sortable=on}} |- || Rail (commuter) | style="text-align:center;"| 32.7 | {{convert|2812|BTU/mi|MJ/km|disp=tablecen|sortable=on}} |- | Air | style="text-align:center;"| 99.3 | {{convert|2826|BTU/mi|MJ/km|disp=tablecen|sortable=on}} |- | Cars | style="text-align:center;"| 1.55 | {{convert|3538|BTU/mi|MJ/km|disp=tablecen|sortable=on}} |- | Personal trucks | style="text-align:center;"| 1.84 | {{convert|3663|BTU/mi|MJ/km|disp=tablecen|sortable=on}} |- | Buses (transit) | style="text-align:center;"| 9.2 | {{convert|4242|BTU/mi|MJ/km|disp=tablecen|sortable=on}} |- | Taxi | style="text-align:center;"| 1.55 | {{convert|15645|BTU/mi|MJ/km|disp=tablecen|sortable=on}} |}
=== US Freight transport === The US transport Energy book states the following figures for freight transport in 2010:<ref name=ornl26-02 /><ref>[http://yosemite.epa.gov/gw/StatePolicyActions.nsf/uniqueKeyLookup/MSTY5Q4MSV?OpenDocument US Environmental protection, 2006] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212164344/http://yosemite.epa.gov/gw/StatePolicyActions.nsf/uniqueKeyLookup/MSTY5Q4MSV?OpenDocument |date=12 February 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/efficiency/ee_ch5.htm Energy Efficiency – Transportation sector] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922145824/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/efficiency/ee_ch5.htm |date=22 September 2008 }} (from the [[United States Department of Energy]]'s [[Energy Information Administration]])</ref><ref>[http://cta.ornl.gov/data/chapter2.shtml Energy] Table 2.15</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- !rowspan=2| transport mode !colspan=2| Fuel consumption |- ! BTU per short ton-mile ! kJ per tonne-kilometre <!-- 1 mi = 1609.344 m 1 ST = 907.18474 kg 1 BTU = 1055.05585262 J --> |- | Domestic waterborne |align=right| 217 |align=right| {{Formatnum:{{#expr:(217*1.05505585262)/(1.609344*0.90718474)round-1}}}} |- | Class 1 railroads |align=right| 289 |align=right| {{Formatnum:{{#expr:(289*1.05505585262)/(1.609344*0.90718474)round0}}}} |- | Heavy trucks |align=right| 3,357 |align=right| {{Formatnum:{{#expr:(3357*1.05505585262)/(1.609344*0.90718474)round0}}}} |- | Air freight (approx.) |align=right| 9,600 |align=right| {{Formatnum:{{#expr:(9600*1.05505585262)/(1.609344*0.90718474)round-2}}}} |} From 1960 to 2010 the efficiency of air freight has increased 75%, mostly due to more efficient jet engines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.hofstra.edu/geotrans/eng/ch3en/conc3en/aircraftenergyefficiency.html|title=Trends in Fuel Efficiency, Selected Passenger Jet Planes|publisher=}}</ref>
1 gal{{sub|-US}} (3.785 l, 0.833 gal{{sub|-imp}}) of fuel can move a ton of cargo 857 km or 462 nmi by barge, or {{convert|337|km|abbr=on}} by rail, or {{convert|98|km|abbr=on}} by truck.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.hofstra.edu/geotrans/eng/ch8en/conc8en/ch8c2en.html|title=Transportation and Energy|first=Dr. Jean-Paul|last=Rodrigue|publisher=}}</ref>
Compare: * Space Shuttle used to transport freight to the other side of the Earth (see above): 40 megajoules per tonne-kilometre. * Net energy for lifting: 10 megajoules per tonne-kilometre.
=== Canadian transport === Natural Resources Canada's Office of Energy Efficiency publishes annual statistics regarding the efficiency of the entire Canadian fleet. For researchers, these fuel consumption estimates are more realistic than the fuel consumption ratings of new vehicles, as they represent the real world driving conditions, including extreme weather and traffic. The annual report is called Energy Efficiency Trends Analysis. There are dozens of tables illustrating trends in energy consumption expressed in energy per passenger km (passengers) or energy per tonne km (freight).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oee.rncan.gc.ca/corporate/statistics/neud/dpa/showTable.cfm?type=AN&sector=tran&juris=00&rn=1&page=4&CFID=31470966&CFTOKEN=5ad089cb084ebfa7-5224C77E-CA7F-D1F6-3D0C65366664F653 |title=2010 data |publisher=Oee.rncan.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=2018-06-19}}</ref>
=== French environmental calculator === The environmental calculator of the French environment and energy agency (ADEME) published in 2007 using data from 2005<ref>(fr) [http://www.ademe.fr/eco-comparateur/ ADEME environmental calculator] which informs about the CO<sub>2</sub> emissions and the [[primary energy]] consumption</ref> enables one to compare the different means of transport as regards the CO<sub>2</sub> emissions (in terms of [[carbon dioxide equivalent]]) as well as the consumption of [[primary energy]]. In the case of an electric vehicle, the ADEME makes the assumption that 2.58 [[tonne of oil equivalent|toe]] as primary energy are necessary for producing one toe of electricity as end energy in France (see [[Embodied energy#In the energy field]]).
This computer tool devised by the ADEME shows the importance of public transport from an environmental point of view. It highlights the primary energy consumption as well as the CO<sub>2</sub> emissions due to transport. Due to the relatively low environmental impact of [[radioactive waste]], compared to that of fossil fuel combustion emissions, this is not a factor in the tool. Moreover, [[intermodal passenger transport]] is probably a key to [[sustainable transport]], by allowing people to use less polluting means of transport.
=== German environmental costs === [[Deutsche Bahn]] calculates their energy consumption for their various routes they take. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Type !! 2015 |- | Regional rail passenger transport (MJ/pkm) || 0.98 |- | Long-distance rail passenger transport (MJ/pkm) || 0.38 |- | Bus service (MJ/Pkm) || 1.22 |- | Rail freight transport (MJ/tkm) || 0.35 |- | Road freight transport (MJ/tkm) || 1.31 |- | Air freight (MJ/tkm) || 10.46 |- | Oceanfreight (MJ/tkm) || 0.11 |}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deutschebahn.com/en/group/ataglance/facts_figures.html |title=Deutsche Bahn |publisher=Deutsche Bahn |date= |accessdate=2018-06-19}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Brake specific fuel consumption]] * [[Fuel economy in automobiles]] * [[Fuel economy-maximizing behaviors]] * [[Fuel management systems]] * [[Marine fuel management]] * [[Thrust specific fuel consumption]] * [[Vehicular metrics]] *[[ACEA agreement]] *[[Alternative propulsion]] *[[Corporate Average Fuel Economy]] (CAFE) *[[Emission standard]] *[[Gasoline gallon equivalent]] *[[Gas-guzzler]] *[[Life cycle assessment]]
== Footnotes == {{Reflist|2}}

page.title: European Multidisciplinary Seafloor and water column Observatory

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "A large-scale European distributed Research Infrastructure for ocean observation" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A large-scale European distributed Research Infrastructure for ocean observation}} {{Infobox organization |name=''European Multidisciplinary Seafloor and water-column Observatory (EMSO)'' |image = European_Multidisciplinary_Seafloor_and_water_column_Observatory_logo.png |caption = EMSO Logo |map = EMSO_member_states.png |mcaption = Involved countries |headquarters = [[Rome]], Italy |membership = 13 involved countries |leader_title = |leader_name = Paolo Favali (Coordinator) |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |formation = |website = [http://www.emso-eu.org/ http://www.emso-eu.org] }}
'''European Multidisciplinary Seafloor and water-column Observatory''' (EMSO) is a large-scale European distributed Research Infrastructure<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/research/infrastructures/index_en.cfm |title=This page is the home page of the RI website - Research Infrastructures - Research - European Commission |publisher=Ec.europa.eu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-14}}</ref> (RI) for ocean observation, enabling real-time interactive long term monitoring of ocean processes. EMSO allows study of the interaction between the [[geosphere]], the [[biosphere]], the [[hydrosphere]], and the [[lithosphere]]; including natural hazards, climate change, and marine ecosystems. EMSO nodes have been deployed at key sites in European seas, starting from the Arctic, through the Atlantic and Mediterranean, to the Black Sea.
==Overview== EMSO is one of the environmental RIs <ref>Paolo Favali, and Laura Beranzoli. "[[:doi:10.1016/j.nima.2008.12.214|EMSO: European multidisciplinary seafloor observatory]]." Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research Section A: Accelerators, Spectrometers, Detectors and Associated Equipment 602.1 (2009): 21-27.</ref> on the Roadmap of the [[European Strategy Forum on Research Infrastructures|European Strategy Forum on Research Infrastructures(ESFRI)]]. The ESRFI Roadmap identifies RIs of pan-European importance that correspond to the long term needs of European research communities.
[[Image:EMSO Sites Map2.jpg|thumb|left|EMSO Sites Map]]
The different EMSO nodes were designed to address topics of regional importance: the biodiversity of mid ocean hot vents in the [[Azores]] region, the rapidly changing environmental conditions affecting the geosphere and biosphere of the Arctic, the deep-water ventilation in the eastern Mediterranean, the active seismicity and the associated geo-hazards of the [[Anatolia]]n region.<ref>[http://www.projectsmagazine.eu.com/randd_projects/exploring_the_last_great_frontier Exploring the last great frontier], Projects Magazine, Issue 10, p. 79-81</ref> EMSO infrastructure has the capacity to observe the deep and open ocean, below, at and above the seafloor, at the European scale, utilizing both stand-alone observing systems, and nodes connected to shore stations through high throughput fibre optic cable.<ref>Favali, P., Beranzoli, L., D’Anna, G., Gasparoni, F., Marvaldi, J., Clauss, G., Gerber, H.W., Nicot, M., Marani, M.P., Gamberi, F., Millot, C., Flueh, E.R., 2006a. A fleet of multiparameter observatories for geophysical and environmental monitoring at seafloor. Annals of Geophysics 49, 659–680</ref> The mission of EMSO is to unite these regional observatories into a common research infrastructure, to implement more generic sensor packages to collect synoptic data series on oceanographic features of more than regional interest, to bring these data together in a uniform format accessible to the general public, and to ensure maintenance of this research infrastructure over a longer time-span than easily maintained by national funding programs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Understanding the misteries of the oceans|publisher=Projects Magazine|issue=n. 29|pages=79–84|url= http://viewer.zmags.com/publication/0ba7a868#/0ba7a868/1|accessdate=2014-02-14}}</ref>
==Ocean observatories== The global oceans cover 70% of the surface of the globe, consist of 95% of the living space, and are the core momentum of our planet’s physical, chemical, and biological cycles. As underlined in recent policy documents such as the '''Galway Statement <ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/research/iscp/pdf/galway_statement_atlantic_ocean_cooperation.pdf |title=Galway Statement on Atlantic Ocean Cooperation |publisher=Ec.europa.eu |accessdate=2014-02-14}}</ref> and Belmont Challenge<ref>{{cite web|url=http://igfagcr.org/index.php/challenge |title=Challenge |publisher=Igfagcr.org |date= |accessdate=2014-02-14}}</ref>''', in order to understand the changes predicted in the coming decades, EMSO aims to have a continuous presence in the oceans; and in order to understand both the slow moving and rapid catastrophes, EMSO seeks to have continuous real-time data from which to learn and to derive adaptation and early warning systems. Ocean observatories provide power and communications to allow a sustained interactive presence in the ocean. This challenge can only be addressed as part of an international cooperation between USA,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coopeus.eu/ |title=Coopeus |publisher=Coopeus.eu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-14}}</ref> Canada, Japan, Australia, Europe and other interested countries where EMSO takes a role for the European side.
==Major science themes== The deployment of the EMSO distributed observatory nodes allows researchers to get useful data in order to understand the behaviour of the oceans and their impact on human society. In particular EMSO collects data concerning the following main scientific fields:<ref>Ruhl, Henry A., et al. "Societal need for improved understanding of climate change, anthropogenic impacts, and geo-hazard warning drive development of ocean observatories in European Seas." Progress in Oceanography 91.1 (2011): 1-33.</ref> *''' Geosciences''': gas hydrate stability, seabed fluid flows, sub-marine landslides, geo-hazard early warning, mid-ocean ridge volcanism. *''' Physical Oceanography''': ocean warming, deep-ocean circulation, benthic and water-column interactions. *''' Biogeochemistry''': ocean acidification and the solubility pump,the biological pump, hypoxia, continental shelf exchange, deep-ocean biogeochemical fluxes. *''' Marine Ecology''': climate forcing of ecosystems, molecules to microbes, fisheries, marine noise, deep biosphere, chemosynthetic ecology.
==EMSO-ERIC== The Preparatory Phase of EMSO was funded by the European [[Seventh Framework Programme#Framework Programme 7|Seventh Framework Programme (FP7)]], involving 12 countries of the European area (Italy, France, Germany, Ireland, Spain, Sweden, Greece, UK, Norway, Portugal, Turkey, the Netherlands), and Romania, that was involved as external interested country from 2010. The Preparatory Phase prepared the foundation for the adoption of the ERIC ([http://ec.europa.eu/research/infrastructures/index_en.cfm?pg=eric [[European Research Infrastructure Consortium]]]), that will be the legal entity in charge of coordinating and facilitating access to these nodes of open ocean fixed point observatory distributed infrastructure.
The EMSO-ERIC will be the central point of contact for observatory initiatives in other parts of the world to set up and promote cooperation in this field. EMSO-ERIC will also integrate research, training, and information dissemination activities for ocean observatory nodes in Europe and to enable scientists and other stakeholders to make efficient use of the EMSO distributed infrastructure around Europe.
==EMSO Partners== * [[National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology|INGV]] * [http://wwz.ifremer.fr/ Ifremer] * [http://www.deutsche-meeresforschung.de/en/home_en.htm KDM] * [http://www.marine.ie/Home/ IMI] * [http://www.utm.csic.es/ UTM-CSIC] * [http://www.gu.se/english/ UGOT] * [http://www.hcmr.gr/ HCMR] * [http://www.noc.soton.ac.uk/ NOCS] * [http://uit.no/ UIT] * [http://www.fc.ul.pt/ FFCUL] * [http://www.emcol.itu.edu.tr/Icerik.aspx?sid=3860 ITU-EMCOL] * [http://www.nioz.nl/ NIOZ] * [http://www.geoecomar.ro/website/index.html GEOECOMAR]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.emso-eu.org/ EMSO Website] * [http://ec.europa.eu/research/infrastructures/index_en.cfm European Research Infrastructure Website] * [http://www.coopeus.eu/ Coopeus]

[[Image:Urn, Palm House.JPG|thumb|right|230px|'''Garden Ornament''': a classical [[Urn]] at Palm House, the [[Belfast Botanic Gardens]], [[Northern Ireland]].]] A '''Garden ornament''' is an item used for [[garden]], [[landscape]], and [[park]] enhancement and decoration.
''The category can include:'' *[[bird bath]]s **[[bird feeder]]s **[[nest box]]es, birdhouses *[[column]]s – [[cast stone]] *[[fountain]]s **rocks and boulders with basins **[[reflecting pool]]s – small/portable types **[[waterfall]]s – small prefabricated type *[[garden furniture]] – motif types *[[Yard globe|gazing spheres]] *[[holiday]] – seasonal [[Christmas ornament|ornament]]s and [[Decorative arts|decoration]]s *[[landscape lighting]] – decorative fixtures *[[outdoor sculpture]] **[[found objects]] such as recycled [[bowling ball]]s, [[toilet]] planters, antique [[farm equipment]] **[[kinetic sculpture]] **[[mask]]s **[[obelisk]]s **[[renewable energy sculpture]] *[[moon bridge]] – small ornament versions *[[pagoda]] – small versions *[[pedestal]]s – e.g. [[terra cotta]], cast stone *[[Pottery|pots]] **[[urns]] **[[ceramic art]] vases *[[statuary]] **[[bathtub madonna]]s **[[concrete goose|concrete geese]] **[[garden gnome]]s **[[lawn jockey]]s **[[plastic flamingo|plastic pink flamingo]]s *[[sundial]]s *[[topiary]] specimens *[[wind chime]]s, [[wind harp]]s *[[weathervane]]s ==History== {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2018}}Early examples of the use of garden ornaments in western culture were seen in [[Roman gardens|Ancient Roman gardens]] such as those excavated at [[Pompeii]] and [[Herculaneum]]. The [[Italian Renaissance garden]] and [[French formal garden]] styles were the peak of using created forms in the garden and landscape, with [[high art]] and [[kitsch]] interpretations ever since. The [[Landscape garden|English landscape garden]] expanded the scale of some garden ornaments to temple [[folly|follies]] The Asian tradition of making garden ornaments, often functioning in association with [[Feng Shui]] principles, has a nearly timeless history. [[Chinese garden]]s with [[Chinese scholar's rocks]], [[Korean stone art]], and [[Japanese garden]]s with [[Suiseki]] and Zen rock gardens have and symbolic meaning and natural ornamental qualities. ==See also== [[Image:German garden gnome.jpg|thumb|right|250px|German [[garden gnome]], in a Wendelin landscape.]] *[[Ornament (architecture)]] *[[Ornamental plant]] *[[Ornamental tree]] *[[Garden design]] *[[Garden feature]] *[[Lawn ornament]] ==External links== *[http://www.gardenvisit.com/garden_product/ornament/ornament.htm Guide to garden ornaments] {{-}} {{Lawn and garden ornaments}} {{sculpture-stub}} [[Category:Garden ornaments| 01]] [[Category:Garden features]] [[Category:Gardening lists]] [[Category:Design-related lists]] [[Category:Types of sculpture]]

revision.comment: fixed citation template(s) to remove page from [[:Category:CS1 maint: Extra text]] & [[WP:AWB/GF|general fixes]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Global mental health''' is the international perspective on different aspects of [[mental health]]. It is 'the area of study, research and practice that places a priority on improving mental health and achieving equity in mental health for all people worldwide'.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=20483977|pmc=3432444|year=2010|author1=Patel|first1=V|title=Global mental health: A new global health field comes of age|journal=JAMA|volume=303|issue=19|pages=1976–7|last2=Prince|first2=M|doi=10.1001/jama.2010.616}}</ref> There is a growing body of criticism of the global mental health movement, and has been widely criticised as a [[Neocolonialism|neo-colonial]] or "missionary" project and as primarily a front for pharmaceutical companies seeking new clients for psychiatric drugs.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/455800587|title=Mental health, race and culture|last=Suman.|first=Fernando,|date=2010|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=9780230212718|edition=3rd|location=Basingstoke, Hampshire|oclc=455800587}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/751584971|title=Crazy like us|last=Ethan.|first=Watters,|isbn=9781849015776|location=London|oclc=751584971}}</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/869802072|title=Mental health worldwide : culture, globalization and development|last=Suman,|first=Fernando,|isbn=9781137329585|location=Houndmills, Basingstoke, Hampshire|oclc=869802072}}</ref><ref name=":1" /><ref>[http://www.globalmentalhealth.org/newsletter_archive/newsletter-may Movement for Global Mental Health Newsletter]. May 2014.</ref>
In theory, taking into account [[cultural differences]] and country-specific conditions, it deals with the [[epidemiology]] of [[mental disorder]]s in different countries, their treatment options, mental health education, political and financial aspects, the structure of mental [[health care]] systems, [[Health human resources|human resources]] in mental health, and [[human rights]] issues among others.
The overall aim of the field of global mental health is to strengthen mental health all over the world by providing information about the mental health situation in all countries, and identifying mental health care needs in order to develop cost-effective interventions to meet those specific needs.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(07)61238-0|pmid= 17804063|year= 2007|author1= Prince|first1= M|title= No health without mental health|journal= Lancet|volume= 370|issue= 9590|pages= 859–77|last2= Patel|first2= V|last3= Saxena|first3= S|last4= Maj|first4= M|last5= Maselko|first5= J|last6= Phillips|first6= M. R.|last7= Rahman|first7= A}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Saxena S, Thornicroft G, Knapp M, Whiteford H |title=Resources for mental health: Scarcity, inequity, and inefficiency|journal=The Lancet|volume=370|issue=9590|pages=878–889|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(07)61239-2|year=2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(07)61242-2|title=Scale up services for mental disorders: A call for action|journal=The Lancet|volume=370|issue=9594|pages=1241–1252|year=2007}}</ref>
== The global burden of disease == [[File:Neuropsychiatric conditions world map - DALY - WHO2002.svg|thumb|[[Disability-adjusted life year]] for neuropsychiatric conditions per 100,000 inhabitants in 2002.{{refbegin|2}} {{legend|#b3b3b3|no data}} {{legend|#ffff65|less than 10}} {{legend|#fff200|10–20}} {{legend|#ffdc00|20–30}} {{legend|#ffc600|30–40}} {{legend|#ffb000|40–50}} {{legend|#ff9a00|50–60}} {{legend|#ff8400|60–80}} {{legend|#ff6e00|80–100}} {{legend|#ff5800|100–120}} {{legend|#ff4200|120–140}} {{legend|#ff2c00|140–150}} {{legend|#cb0000|more than 150}} {{refend}}]]
Mental, [[neurological]], and substance use disorders make a substantial contribution to the [[Disease burden|global burden of disease]] (GBD).<ref>World Health Organization. [http://www.who.int/healthinfo/bod/en/index.html ''Global burden of disease'']. Geneva, WHO Health statistics and health information systems. Accessed 15 March 2011.</ref> This is a global measure of so-called [[disability-adjusted life year]]s (DALY's) assigned to a certain disease/disorder, which is a sum of the years lived with disability and years of life lost due to this disease within the total population. [[Neuropsychiatry|Neuropsychiatric]] conditions account for 14% of the global burden of disease. Among [[non-communicable disease]]s, they account for 28% of the DALY's – more than [[cardiovascular disease]] or [[cancer]]. However, it is estimated that the real contribution of [[mental disorders]] to the global burden of disease is even higher, due to the complex interactions and co-morbidity of physical and mental illness.
Around the world, almost one million people die due to suicide every year, and it is the third leading cause of death among young people. The most important causes of disability due to health-related conditions worldwide include [[unipolar depression]], [[alcoholism]], [[schizophrenia]], [[bipolar depression]] and [[dementia]]. In low- and middle-income countries, these conditions represent a total of 19.1% of all disability related to health conditions.<ref>World Health Organization: [http://www.who.int/mental_health/policy/mhtargeting/development_targeting_mh_summary.pdf ''Mental Health and Development: Targeting People with Mental Health Conditions as Vulnerable Group''.] Accessed 15 March 2011.</ref>
== Treatment gap == It is estimated that one in four people in the world will be affected by mental or neurological disorders at some point in their lives.<ref>World Health Organization: [http://www.who.int/whr/2001/media_centre/press_release/en/index.html ''Mental disorders affect one in four people.''] Accessed 15 March 2011.</ref> Although many effective interventions for the treatment of mental disorders are known, and awareness of the need for treatment of people with mental disorders has risen, the proportion of those who need mental health care but who do not receive it remains very high. This so-called "treatment gap" is estimated to reach between 76–85% for low- and middle-income countries, and 35–50% for high-income countries.
Despite the acknowledged need, for the most part there have not been substantial changes in mental health care delivery during the past years.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turekian|first1=Vaughan|title=Mental Health Diplomacy|journal=Science & Diplomacy|date=2014-06-23|volume=3|issue=2|url=http://www.sciencediplomacy.org/editorial/2014/mental-health-diplomacy-building-global-response}}</ref> Main reasons for this problem are public health priorities, lack of a mental health policy and legislation in many countries, a lack of resources – financial and human resources – as well as inefficient resource allocation.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(07)61263-X|title=Barriers to improvement of mental health services in low-income and middle-income countries|journal=The Lancet|volume=370|issue=9593|pages=1164–1174|year=2007|last1=Saraceno|first1=Benedetto|last2=Van Ommeren|first2=Mark|last3=Batniji|first3=Rajaie|last4=Cohen|first4=Alex|last5=Gureje|first5=Oye|last6=Mahoney|first6=John|last7=Sridhar|first7=Devi|last8=Underhill|first8=Chris | pmid = 17804061 }}</ref>
In 2011, the World Health Organization estimated a shortage of 1.18 million [[mental health professional]]s, including 55,000 psychiatrists, 628,000 nurses in mental health settings, and 493,000 psychosocial care providers needed to treat mental disorders in 144 low- and middle-income countries. The annual wage bill to remove this [[Health Human Resources|health workforce]] shortage was estimated at about US$4.4 billion.<ref>Scheffler RM et al. (2011). [http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2011/9789241501019_eng.pdf ''Human resources for mental health: workforce shortages in low- and middle-income countries'']. Geneva, World Health Organization Press.</ref>
== Interventions == Information and evidence about cost-effective interventions to provide better mental health care are available. Although most of the research (80%) has been carried out in high-income countries, there is also strong evidence from low- and middle-income countries that [[pharmacology|pharmacological]] and [[psychosocial]] interventions are effective ways to treat mental disorders, with the strongest evidence for depression, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and hazardous alcohol use.
Recommendations to strengthen mental health systems around the world have been first mentioned in the WHO's [[World Health Report|''World Health Report 2001'']],<ref>World Health Organization. (2001) [http://www.who.int/whr/2001/en/index.html ''The world health report 2001 – Mental Health: New Understanding, New Hope'']. Geneva, WHO Press.</ref> which focused on mental health:
# Provide treatment in primary care # Make [[psychotropic drug]]s available # Give care in the community # Educate the public # Involve communities, families and consumers # Establish national policies, programs and [[legislation]] # Develop [[Health Human Resources|human resources]] # Link with other sectors # Monitor community mental health # Support more research
Based on the data of 12 countries, assessed by the ''WHO Assessment Instrument for Mental Health Systems'' (WHO-AIMS),<ref>World Health Organization: [http://www.who.int/mental_health/evidence/WHO-AIMS/en/''Assessment Instrument for Mental Health Systems''.] Accessed 15 March 2011.</ref> the costs of scaling up mental health services by providing a core treatment package for schizophrenia, bipolar affective disorder, depressive episodes and hazardous alcohol use have been estimated. Structural changes in mental health systems according to the WHO recommendations have been taken into account.
For most countries, this model suggests an initial period of investment of US$0.30 – 0.50 per person per year. The total expenditure on mental health would have to rise at least ten-fold in low-income countries. In those countries, additional financial resources will be needed, while in middle- and high-income countries the main challenge will be the reallocation of resources within the health system to provide better mental health service.
==Prevention==
Prevention is beginning to appear in mental health strategies, including the 2004 WHO report "Prevention of Mental Disorders", the 2008 EU "Pact for Mental Health" and the 2011 US National Prevention Strategy. NIMH or the National Institute of Mental Health has over 400 grants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nimh.nih.gov/research-priorities/research-areas/index.shtml|title=NIMH » Research Areas|website=www.nimh.nih.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-10-06}}</ref>
==Stakeholders==
=== World Health Organization (WHO) ===
Two of WHO's core programmes for mental health are WHO MIND (Mental health improvements for Nations Development) and Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP).
WHO MIND focuses on 5 areas of action to ensure concrete changes in people's daily lives. These are: # Action in and support to countries to improve mental health, such as the WHO Pacific Island Mental Health network (PIMHnet) # Mental health policy, planning and service development # Mental health human rights and legislation # Mental health as a core part of human development # The QualityRights Project which works to unite and empower people to improve the quality of care and promote human rights in mental health facilities and social care homes.
Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP) is WHO’s action plan to scale up services for mental, neurological and substance use disorders for countries especially with low and lower middle incomes. The aim of mhGAP is to build partnerships for collective action and to reinforce the commitment of governments, international organizations and other stakeholders.
The mhGAP Intervention Guide (mhGAP-IG) was launched in October 2010. It is a technical tool for the management of mental, neurological and substance use disorders in non-specialist health settings. The priority conditions included are: depression, psychosis, bipolar disorders, epilepsy, developmental and behavioural disorders in children and adolescents, dementia, alcohol use disorders, drug use disorders, self-harm/suicide and other significant emotional or medically unexplained complaints.
== Criticism ==
One of the most prominent critics of the Movement for Global Mental Health has been China Mills, author of the book ''Decolonizing Global Mental Health: The Psychiatrization of the Majority World''.
Mills writes that:<ref name=":1">Mills, China. [https://www.academia.edu/4905979/Decolonizing_Global_Mental_Health_The_Psychiatrization_of_the_Majority_World Decolonizing Global Mental Health: The Psychiatrization of the Majority World]. Retrieved October 17, 2014, from</ref>
{{Quote|text=This book charts the creeping of psychology and psychiatry across the borders of everyday experience and across geographical borders, as a form of colonialism that comes from within and from outside, swallowed in the form of a pill. It maps an anxious space where socio-economic crises come to be reconfigured as individual crisis – as 'mental illness'; and how potentially violent interventions come to be seen as 'essential' treatment.|sign=|source=}}
Another prominent critic is Ethan Watters, author of ''Crazy Like Us: The Globalization of the American Psyche''.<ref name=":0">Watters, Ethan (January 8, 2010). [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/10/magazine/10psyche-t.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 The Americanization of Mental Illness]. ''The New York Times''.</ref>

(2001) ''World health report 2001—mental health: new understanding, new hope''. Geneva, WHO Press]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Joachim Barrande |image =Barrandepic.jpg |image_size = 230px |caption = Joachim Barrande |birth_date = {{birth-date|11 August 1799}} |birth_place = [[Saugues]], [[Haute Loire]] |death_date = {{death-date and age|5 October 1883|11 August 1799}} |death_place = [[Frohsdorf]] |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[France|French]] |ethnicity = |field = [[geology]]
[[palaeontology]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = [[École Polytechnique]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = Barrande |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes =[[Wollaston Medal]] {{small|(1857)}} |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }}'''Joachim Barrande''' (11 August 1799 – 5 October 1883) was a [[France|French]] [[geologist]] and [[palaeontologist]]. [[File:Joachim Barrande01.jpg|thumb|
Plate from ''Système silurien du centre de la Bohême'']] ==Career== Barrande was born at [[Saugues]], [[Haute Loire]], and educated in the [[École Polytechnique]] and [[École des ponts ParisTech|École Nationale des Ponts et Chaussées]] at [[Paris]]. Although he had received the training of an [[engineer]], his first appointment was that of tutor to the duc de Bordeaux (afterwards known as the [[comte de Chambord]]), grandson of [[Charles X of France|Charles X]], and when the king abdicated in 1830, Barrande accompanied the royal exiles to [[England]] and [[Scotland]], and afterwards to [[Prague]]. Settling in that city in 1831, he became occupied in engineering works, and his attention was then attracted to the fossils from the Lower [[Palaeozoic]] rocks of [[Bohemia]]. The publication in 1839 of ''Murchison's [[Silurian]] System'' incited Barrande to carry on systematic researches on the equivalent strata in [[Bohemia]]. For ten years (1840–1850) he made a detailed study of these rocks, engaging workmen specially to collect fossils, and in this way he obtained upwards of 3500 species of [[graptolite]]s, [[brachiopoda]], [[mollusca]], [[trilobite]]s and [[fish]]es. The first volume of his great work, ''Système silurien du centre de la Bohême'' (dealing with trilobites, several genera, including ''[[Deiphon]]'', which he personally described), appeared in 1852; and from that date until 1881, he issued twenty-one quarto volumes of text and plates. Two other volumes were issued after his death in 1887 and 1894. It is estimated that he spent nearly £10,000 on these works. In addition he published a large number of separate papers. In recognition of his important researches the [[Geological Society of London]] in 1857 awarded to him the [[Wollaston medal]]. In 1870, he was elected a foreign member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]]. He was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1875.{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780-2010: Chapter B|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterB.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=17 May 2011}} Barrande died at [[Frohsdorf]] on 5 October 1883. His extensive collection has been stored in [http://www.nm.cz/Natural-History-Museum/ National Museum] in Prague on grounds of his testament. In 1884 the Barrande Rocks in Prague was named in honor of the scientist and massive plaque with Barrande's name was added at the rocks. On 24 February 1928, a district of [[Prague]], ''[[Barrandov]]'', was named after him. ==Opposition to evolution== Barrande was an advocate of the theory of [[Catastrophism|catastrophes]] (as taught by [[Georges Cuvier]]), thus opposing [[Charles Darwin]]'s theory of evolution. He rejected [[transmutation of species]]. He also wrote a five-volume book on the defense of his theory of so-called "colonies", presuming that the cause of the presence of fossils typical for one layer surrounded by those typical for another is atectonical. He tended to name those colonies with names of his scientific adversaries. His anti-evolutionary views were criticized by geologist [[Henry Hicks (geologist)|Henry Hicks]] who commented that "Barrande is well known to be a determined opponent to the theory of evolution, and doubtless this strong bias has prevented him from seeing and accepting many facts which would otherwise, to so keen and careful an observer, have seemed inconsistent with such strong views."Hicks, Henry. (1874). [https://www.nature.com/articles/009261b0 ''M. Barrande and Darwinism'']. ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' 9: 261–262. {{botanist|Barrande|Barrande, Joachim|border=0}} ==References== {{Reflist}} * {{Cite journal |pmid = 17782936 |publication-date=Dec 7, 1883 |date=Dec 1883 |title=Joachim Barrande |volume=2 |issue=44 |periodical=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |pages=727–729 |doi = 10.1126/science.ns-2.44.727 |postscript ={{inconsistent citations}} |bibcode = 1883Sci.....2..727. }} * {{Cite journal |pmid = 17730762 |publication-date=Nov 30, 1883 |date=Nov 1883 |title=Joachim Barrande |volume=2 |issue=43 |periodical=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |pages=669–701 |doi = 10.1126/science.ns-2.43.669 |postscript = {{inconsistent citations}}}} * {{Cite EB1911|wstitle=Barrande, Joachim}} ==Further reading== *Jiří Kříž, John Pojeta, Jr. and Barrande. (1974). ''Barrande's Colonies Concept and a Comparison of His Stratigraphy with the Modern Stratigraphy of the Middle Bohemian Lower Paleozoic Rocks (Barrandian) of Czechoslovakia''. ''[[Journal of Paleontology]]'' 48 (3): 489-494. ==External links== {{commons category|Joachim Barrande}} * [http://www.trilobit.biz/joachim.html Detailed biography] * [http://nts2.cgu.cz/pls/portal30/docs/FOLDER/SVET_GEOLOGIE/OSOBNOSTI/BARRANDE/JOACHIM_BARRANDE.HTM Detailed biography (in Czech, with details of his stay in Bohemia)] * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Joachim Barrande}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150924062602/http://www.europeana.eu/portal/search.html?query=who%3A%28Barrande%2C+J.+col.+%28collector%29%29&rows=96&start=1345&qt=false part of his collection accessible online via Europeana] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barrande, Joachim}} [[Category:1799 births]] [[Category:1883 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century French people]] [[Category:19th-century Czech people]] [[Category:Catastrophism]] [[Category:Czech paleontologists]] [[Category:Czech geologists]] [[Category:French geologists]] [[Category:French paleontologists]] [[Category:Paleobotanists]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Corresponding Members of the St Petersburg Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Wollaston Medal winners]] [[Category:École Polytechnique alumni]] [[Category:Czech people of French descent]] [[Category:People from Haute-Loire]] [[Category:French Roman Catholics]]
