page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on elms

revision.text:
'''[[Elm]]s''' (''Ulmus'' species) are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] species including:
==[[phagy|Monophagous]]== Species that feed exclusively on ''Ulmus''
* [[Bucculatricidae]] ** ''[[Bucculatrix albedinella]]'' ** ''[[Bucculatrix eclecta]]'' ** ''[[Bucculatrix ulmifoliae]]'' * [[Coleophoridae]] ** ''[[Coleophora ulmifoliella]]'' * [[Gelechiidae]] ** ''[[Carpatolechia fugitivella]]'' * [[Geometridae]] ** [[Blomer's rivulet]] (''Discoloxia blomeri'') <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=647]</ref> ** [[Clouded magpie]] (''Abraxas sylvata'') <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=1382]</ref> * [[Gracillariidae]] ** ''[[Phyllonorycter schreberella]]'' <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=2354]</ref> ** ''[[Phyllonorycter tristrigella]]'' <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=2358]</ref> * [[Lycaenidae]] ** [[White-letter hairstreak]] (''Satyrium w-album'') <ref>[http://www.ukbutterflies.co.uk/species.php?vernacular_name=White-Letter+Hairstreak#Larva]</ref> * [[Lymantriidae]] ** [[Black V moth]] (''Arctornis l-nigrum'') <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=577]</ref> * [[Nepticulidae]] ** ''[[Stigmella lemniscella]]'' <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=3473]</ref> ** ''[[Stigmella viscerella]]'' <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leafmines.co.uk/html/lepidoptera/S.viscerella2.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006081652/http://www.leafmines.co.uk/html/Lepidoptera/S.viscerella2.htm |archivedate=2007-10-06 |df= }}</ref> * [[Noctuidae]] ** [[Dusky lemon sallow]] (''Xanthia gilvago'') <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=1265]</ref> ** [[Lesser spotted pinion]] (''Cosmia affinis'') <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?bf=2316]</ref> ** [[White-spotted pinion moth]] (''Cosmia diffinis'') <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?bf=2317]</ref> * [[Pyralidae]] ** ''[[Pempelia formosa]]'' <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=2455]</ref> * [[Tortricidae]] ** ''[[Acleris boscana]]'' <ref>[https://ukmoths.org.uk/show.php?id=2413]</ref>
==[[phagy|Polyphagous]]== Species that feed on ''Ulmus'' among other plants [[Image:Buff Tip larva.jpg|thumb|right| 300px|[[Buff-tip]] larva on [[European white elm]], Great Fontley, England]] * [[Bucculatricidae]] ** ''[[Bucculatrix ulmella]]'' * [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearer species: ***''[[Coleophora badiipennella]]'' ***''[[Coleophora cerasivorella]]'' ***''[[Coleophora comptoniella]]'' ***''[[Coleophora fuscedinella]]'' ***''[[Coleophora limosipennella]]'' ***''[[Coleophora serratella]]'' * [[Geometridae]] ** [[Autumnal moth]] (''Epirrita autumnata'') ** [[Dotted border]] (''Agriopis marginaria'') ** [[Engrailed (moth)|Engrailed]] (''Ectropis crepuscularia'') ** [[Feathered thorn]] (''Colotois pennaria'') ** [[Light emerald]] (''Campaea margaritata'') ** [[Mottled umber]] (''Erannis defoliaria'') ** [[November moth]] (''Epirrita dilutata'') ** [[Pale November moth]] (''Epirrita christyi'') ** [[Scarce umber]] (''Agriopis {{featured list}} [[File:Heavyrainloop092210.gif|thumb|Satellite loop of the remnants of [[Tropical Storm Georgette (2010)|Tropical Storm Georgette]] in 2010 affecting New Mexico]] The inland [[U.S. state]] of [[New Mexico]] has experienced impacts from 81 known [[tropical cyclones]] and their remnants. There have been 68 known tropical cyclones from the [[Pacific hurricane|Eastern Pacific]] that affected the state, compared to only 13 such [[Atlantic hurricane]]s. The biggest threat from such storms in the state is their associated rainfall and flooding. The wettest storm was from the remnants of an Atlantic storm in [[1941 Atlantic hurricane season|1941]] that produced {{convert|11.33|in|mm|abbr=on}} of precipitation. Since 1950, the highest rainfall total recorded was {{convert|9.8|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Canton, New Mexico|Canton]], also associated with an Atlantic storm in [[1954 Atlantic hurricane season|1954]]. The rains in 1954 resulted in flooding in six towns that killed at least four people. Other deadly rainfall events from tropical cyclone remnants include [[Hurricane Dolly (2008)|Hurricane Dolly]] in [[2008 Atlantic hurricane season|2008]] and [[Tropical Storm Georgette (2010)|Tropical Storm Georgette]] in [[2010 Pacific hurricane season|2010]]. The former swept away a person along the [[Rio Ruidoso]] and caused $25 million in damage (2008 [[United States dollar|USD]]), which was the most damaging storm event. The floods damaged 500 buildings and destroyed 13 bridges. The latter caused heavy rains that resulted in one death in the [[Rio Grande]].
==Climatology== [[File:New Mexico topographic.jpg|thumb|Topographical map of New Mexico|alt=A map of a state's terrain, with brown and white colors representing higher elevations, and yellow and green colors representing lower elevations. County borders are also shown on the map.]] Due to New Mexico's position in the southwestern United States, there are three primary causes for flooding within the state in the autumn months: the effects of tropical cyclones, the [[North American Monsoon]], or an approaching [[cold front]]. Tropical cyclones from both the [[North Atlantic tropical cyclone|Atlantic]] and [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific]] oceans can affect New Mexico, usually in southern regions. Storms that originate from the Atlantic Ocean usually move through the [[Gulf of Mexico]] on a northwest trajectory, typically during the month of September. Tropical cyclones from the eastern Pacific usually maintain a fast north-northeast track, occasionally through the [[Gulf of California]], and generally affect the state from the middle of September to the middle of October. The accompanying moisture of the Pacific storms encounter the mountains of the state, and through [[orographic lift]], produce heavy rainfall. Due to the storms' fast movement, the rainfall events accompanying Pacific storms are generally shorter lasting and more concentrated than other such storms in the state.<ref name="hrd">{{cite journal|author=HDR Engineering, Inc.|title=Preliminary New Mexico Extreme Precipitation Event Climatology|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.hdrweather.com/publications/reports/EPAT_NM.pdf|format=PDF}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In an average year, the remnants of 3.1 Pacific tropical cyclones affect the southwestern United States. In some locations, the systems provide 30% of the annual rainfall.<ref name="inf"/> In New Mexico, however, stations' annual rainfall from tropical cyclones range from 10% in the western portion to less than 5% in the eastern.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Contribution of Eastern North Pacific Tropical Cyclones to the Rainfall Climatology of the Southwest United States|author=Kristen L. Corbosier|author2=Michael J. Dickinson|author3=Lance F. Bosart|date=August 2009|volume=137|doi= 10.1175/2009MWR2768.1|pages=2417, 2426|journal=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/2009MWR2768.1|issue=8|bibcode = 2009MWRv..137.2415C }}</ref> Rainfall from tropical cyclones affect the [[Albuquerque International Sunport]] an average of 3.9 days per year.<ref name="inf">{{cite journal|author=Elizabeth A. Ritchie and Kimberly M. Woo|author2=David S. Gutzler|author3=Sarah R. White|page=196|title=The Influence of Eastern Pacific Tropical Cyclone Remnants on the Southwestern United States|volume=139|journal=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=American Meteorological Society|doi=10.1175/2010MWR3389.1|date=January 2011|bibcode = 2011MWRv..139..192R }}</ref> Storms affect New Mexico less than [[Arizona]], and are generally weaker. The greatest threat from such storms are accompanying floods. Damage from tropical cyclones is expected to increase as the population increases in the southwestern United States.<ref name="ISPE">{{cite web|author=Rebecca Carter | date=August 2002 | title=Tropical Storm Impacts on Arizona and New Mexico | accessdate=2012-01-27 | publisher=Climate Assessment for the Southwest Project, Institute for the Study of Planet Earth, University of Arizona | url=http://www.climas.arizona.edu/files/climas/pdfs/feature-articles/2002_aug_tropicalstorms.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060926225918/http://www.ispe.arizona.edu/climas/forecasts/articles/tropical_Aug2002.pdf |archivedate = 2006-09-26 | format = PDF}}</ref>
==List of storms==
===Before 1950=== *October 4, 1911 – Influenced by an approaching [[extratropical cyclone]], the remnants of a tropical cyclone crossed the [[Gulf of California]] and Arizona into New Mexico, producing {{convert|2|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in some areas.<ref name="colo">{{cite book|year=1981|title=Meteorology of Important Rainstorms in the Colorado River and Great Basin Draingage|publisher=National Weather Service|location=Silver Spring, Maryland|page=30|author=E. Marshall Hansen|author2=Francis K. Schwartz|accessdate=2012-02-03|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951d00827437l}}</ref> *September 18, 1918 – The remnants of a Pacific hurricane moved through the northern portion of the state.<ref name="calif"/> *September 16, 1919 – After striking Texas as a hurricane, a [[1919 Florida Keys hurricane|tropical depression]] dissipated over western Texas. Its remnants produced {{convert|2.84|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in Roswell.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|year=2008|accessdate=2012-01-31|title=Raw Observations for 1919 Storm 2|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/RawData/1919/191902.xls|format=XLS}}</ref> *October 1, 1921 – The remnants of a Pacific hurricane moved through the northern portion of the state.<ref name="calif"/> *August 27, 1932 – A landfalling storm near [[Culiacán]], [[Sinaloa]] produced heavy rainfall in the southwestern New Mexico for three days.<ref name="calif"/> *September 8, 1936 – After moving through the Sea of Cortez into Arizona, the remnants of a tropical cyclone dropped {{convert|1.97|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Datil, New Mexico|Datil]].<ref name="calif"/> *September 2, 1938 – The remnants of a Pacific storm produced rainfall in the state.<ref name="hrd"/> *September 18, 1941 – The remnants of an Atlantic storm dropped {{convert|11.33|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in a 24‑hour period.<ref name="hrd"/> *August 31, 1942 – A hurricane struck Texas and dissipated over southern New Mexico, producing {{convert|9|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in 28 hours.<ref name="hrd"/> The rainfall caused flooding in the [[Pecos River|Pecos]] and [[Canadian River|Canadian]] rivers. In one station along the Pecos River, the floods produced a [[Discharge (hydrology)|discharge]] of 48,600 cubic feet per second (0.028 cubic meters per second), which was a [[return period|1 in 100 year]] event.<ref name="geo">{{cite web|author=R.W. Paulson, at al.|title=Major Floods and Droughts in New Mexico|publisher=United States Geological Survey|date=2004-05-18|accessdate=2012-02-03|url=http://geochange.er.usgs.gov/sw/impacts/hydrology/state_fd/nmwater1.html}}</ref>
===1950s=== [[File:Oct1954tdfilledrainblk.gif|right|thumb|Rainfall summary for a tropical depression in 1954]] *1951 – The remnants of a Pacific tropical cyclone affected the state.<ref name="nwss"/> *October 7, 1954 – Rains subsided from a [[1954 Atlantic hurricane season#Unnumbered Tropical Depression|tropical depression]] that crossed from Texas into New Mexico. The highest precipitation was {{convert|9.8|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Canton, New Mexico|Canton]], which was the greatest rainfall total associated with a tropical cyclone in the state since 1950. The rainfall caused flooding in Roswell and along the Pecos River system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/tdofoct1954.html|title=Tropical Depression — October 3–7, 1954|author=David M. Roth |date=2007-06-20|publisher=[[Weather Prediction Center]]|accessdate=2012-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=L.F. Hubert|author2=Otto Berg|journal=Monthly Weather Review|date=June 1955|pages=119–124|title=A Rocket Portrait of a Tropical Storm|accessdate=2011-08-04|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/083/mwr-083-06-0119.pdf|format=PDF|bibcode=1955MWRv...83..119H |volume=83|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1955)083<0119:ARPOAT>2.0.CO;2|issue=6}}</ref>{{US States Tropical Cyclone Point Maxima}} The flooding caused millions in damage after flooding affected six towns and highways across the region. There were four confirmed fatalities with seven missing in the days after the storm.<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|date=1954-10-04|title=New Mexico Floods Drown 4; 7 Missing|newspaper=The Milwaukee Sentinel|accessdate=2012-01-31|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6rkyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3A8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=5135,5975627&dq=new-mexico+flooding&hl=en}}</ref> *1954 – In addition to the previous storm, the remnants of a Pacific tropical cyclone affected the state.<ref name="nwss"/> *October 6, 1957 – After crossing northwestern Mexico, a tropical depression dissipated in the southern portion of the state.{{EPAC hurricane best track}} *1957 – In addition to the previous storm, the remnants of another Pacific system affected the state.<ref name="nwss"/> *September 12, 1958 – A tropical storm dissipated over Baja California, spreading rainfall into the state.<ref name="atmos"/> *October 6, 1958 – A tropical depression from the Pacific dissipated over the state, after crossing [[Sonora]] and Arizona. This was exactly a year after another depression dissipated in the state.{{EPAC hurricane best track}} The depression produced rainfall in the state.<ref name="calif">{{cite book|author=Arnold Court|publisher=California State University|location=Northridge, California|year=1980|title=Tropical Cyclone Effects on California|pages=11, 13, 14, 16, 18|accessdate=2012-02-02|url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?seq=1&id=uc1.31822009671892&view=image&q1=new+mexico&start=1&size=100&page=root&orient=0}}</ref> *1959–1961 – The Albuquerque National Weather Service reported that the remnants of a Pacific storm affected the state in each of the years.<ref name="nwss"/>
===1960s=== *September 27, 1962 – [[1962 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Claudia|Tropical Storm Claudia]] dissipated over the Baja California peninsula and produced over 25% of the warm-season rainfall in portions of New Mexico.<ref name="atmos"/> The remnants of another storm in the year also affected the state.<ref name="nwss"/> *1964–1967 – The Albuquerque National Weather Service reported that the remnants of a Pacific storm affected the state in each of the years.<ref name="nwss"/> *August 20, 1968 – The remnants of [[1968 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Hyacinth|Tropical Storm Hyacinth]] spread into the state with thunderstorms and light rainfall.<ref>{{cite journal|author=William J. Deney|date=March 1969|journal=Monthly Weather Review|volume=97|page=215|title=The Eastern Pacific Hurricane Season of 1968|accessdate=2012-01-30|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/097/mwr-097-03-0207.pdf|format=PDF|issue=3|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1969)097<0207:tephso>2.3.co;2|bibcode = 1969MWRv...97..207D }}</ref> *October 3, 1968 – Portions of the state experienced rainfall from dissipating [[Hurricane Pauline (1968)|Hurricane Pauline]].<ref>{{cite news|agency=United Press International|date=1968-10-04|title=Weather is Clear, Frosty|newspaper=Williamstown Daily News|accessdate=2012-01-30|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SY1DAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mq4MAAAAIBAJ&pg=3264,273408&dq=pauline+new-mexico&hl=en}}</ref> *In addition to the previous two systems, the remnants of a third storm affected the state. According to the Albuquerque National Weather Service, 1968 had the most storms affecting the state.<ref name="nwss"/>
===1970s=== *August 5, 1970 – [[Hurricane Celia|Tropical Depression Celia]] maintained a well-defined circulation until it dissipated over the southeast portion of the state, after causing heavy damage in southeastern Texas. The system dropped over {{convert|2|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in some areas, but its associated winds were not strong.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Hurricane Center|title=Celia's Later Life|accessdate=2012-01-30|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/cdmp/dvd0033-jpg/1970/atlantic/celia/postevent/celialaterlife.jpg|format=JPG}}</ref> *September 5, 1970 – Moisture from [[Tropical Storm Norma (1970)|Tropical Storm Norma]] from the Pacific combined with a cold front to produce heavy rainfall of about {{convert|12|in|mm|abbr=on}}, causing flooding near the [[Four Corners]] region.<ref name="hrd"/><ref>{{cite journal|author=R.H. Roeske|author2=M.E. Cooley|author3=B.N. Aldridge|title=Floods of September 1970 in Arizona, Utah, Colorado, and New Mexico|publisher=United States Department of the Interior|year=1978|url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/wsp/2052/report.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 1, 1971 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Irene-Olivia|Hurricane Olivia]] dropped {{convert|2.23|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Zuni, New Mexico|Zuni]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=1971-10-04|title=Weekly Weather and Crop Bulletin|volume=58|accessdate=2012-01-30|url=http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/waob/weather_weekly//1970s/1971/weather_weekly-10-04-1971.pdf|format=PDF|issue=40}}</ref> *October 7, 1972 – [[1972 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Joanne|Tropical Depression Joanne]] dissipated over northwestern Mexico, producing {{convert|2.48|in|mm|abbr=on}} in Albuquerque.<ref name="swrain"/> *October 2, 1976 – [[Hurricane Liza (1976)|Hurricane Liza]] struck northwestern Mexico and dissipated, although its remnants dropped light rain in the state that reached {{convert|0.47|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[White Sands National Monument]].<ref name="swrain"/> *August 18, 1977 – As [[Hurricane Doreen (1977)|Tropical Depression Doreen]] dissipated near California, its outskirts produced {{convert|2.05|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in the city of Florida.<ref name="swrain"/> *October 7, 1977 – [[1977 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Heather|Hurricane Heather]] dissipated to the west of [[Baja California]]. Its remnants spread rainfall across the southwest United States, including a statewide peak of {{convert|3.17|in|mm|abbr=on}} near [[Yeso, New Mexico|Yeso]].<ref name="swrain"/> *September 1978 – The remnants of a Pacific tropical cyclone dropped at least {{convert|6.35|in|mm|abbr=on}} in the [[Guadalupe Mountains]] in the southeast portion of the state.<ref name="hrd"/>
===1980s=== *August 12, 1980 – After making landfall near the mouth of the [[Rio Grande]], [[Hurricane Allen]] dissipated near the Texas/New Mexico border. The storm produced rainfall across the state.<ref>{{cite journal|author=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|volume=67|title=Weekly Weather and Crop Bulletin|date=1980-08-19|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://usda01.library.cornell.edu/usda/waob/weather_weekly//1980s/1980/weather_weekly-08-19-1980.pdf|format=PDF|issue=34}}</ref> *July 30, 1981 – The remnant circulation of a [[1981 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Depression Four|tropical depression]] from the Atlantic dissipated over northern Texas. Its moisture extended into New Mexico, and {{convert|6.12|in|mm|abbr=on}} fell at [[Hobbs, New Mexico|Hobbs]].<ref name="swrain"/><ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|date=2008-05-17|title=Tropical Depression Four - July 24–30, 1981|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/td4of1981.html}}</ref> *October 1, 1982 – Heavy rainfall of over {{convert|4|in|mm|abbr=on}} spread across the state after [[Hurricane Paul (1982)|Hurricane Paul]] struck Baja California and dissipated. The rains caused crop and property damage.<ref>{{cite news|date=1982-10-01|title=Local, National, International Weather|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Journal|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zBgiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=P2gEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6801,19957&dq=hurricane+paul&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |volume=24 |title=September 1982 Storm Data |accessdate=2013-01-05 |publisher=National Climatic Data Center |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FGqf8R1g?url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-1E6290A9-DEF0-4052-BB6B-531FF5F941DB.pdf |archivedate=2013-03-20 |url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-2B0E1597-D4C3-4BC9-A34C-7459624D6BF4.pdf |format=PDF |issue=9 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *October 2, 1983 – Tropical Depression Octave dissipated offshore western Mexico, although it contributed to [[October 1983 Southwest United States floods|widespread flooding and rainfall]] across the southwestern United States. Rainfall in New Mexico reached {{convert|5.42|in|mm|abbr=on}} near [[Luna, New Mexico|Luna]]. The rains caused flooding that forced people from their homes and damaged a portion of [[U.S. Route 180]]. New Mexico governor [[Toney Anaya]] declared a state of emergency in [[Catron County, New Mexico|Catron County]].<ref name="swrain"/><ref>{{cite news|author=Arthur E. Rotstein|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=The Spokesman-Review|title=Arizona Flood Damage Climbs|date=1983-10-04|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kVdWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6e4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6994,1738214&dq=mexico+flood&hl=en}}</ref> *October 19, 1983 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Tico (1983)|Hurricane Tico]] dropped over {{convert|3|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in the southeastern portion of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|date=2007-03-20|title=Hurricane Tico - October 18–24, 1983|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//tico1983.html}}</ref> *September 26, 1984 – Flash flood warnings were posted across the state due to rainfall from the remnants of [[Hurricane Norbert (1984)|Hurricane Norbert]].<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|date=1984-09-26|title=Domestic News}}</ref> *October 3, 1984 – The remnants of [[1984 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Polo|Hurricane Polo]] dropped about {{convert|2|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in [[Reserve, New Mexico|Reserve]].<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|date=1984-10-03|title=Remnants of Hurricane Polo Dump Rain on Southwest}}</ref> *October 9, 1985 – Flash floods affected the southern one–third of the state from rainfall associated with the remnants of [[Hurricane Waldo (1985)|Hurricane Waldo]]. The hurricane previously dissipated over Mexico, and the resulting floods was due to heavy rainfall that peaked at {{convert|6.66|in|mm|abbr=on}} in Hobbs. Damage was estimated between $100,000–$1 million (1985 USD), mostly to crops, roads, and buildings.<ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|date=2007-03-14|title=Hurricane Waldo - October 5–12, 1985|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//waldo1985.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |page=25 |title=Storm Data October 1985 |volume=27 |publisher=National Climatic Data Center |accessdate=2012-03-26 |archivedate=2013-03-20 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FGqWiHKy?url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-58E239DC-3C7B-448A-A87E-2C6B1BB49C93.pdf |url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-44212CDA-6CF0-46E3-9200-B75C70EF062D.pdf |format=PDF |issue=10 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *September 24, 1986 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Newton (1986)|Hurricane Newton]] crossed the southeastern portion of the state with scattered rainshowers.<ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|date=2007-04-30|title=Hurricane Newton - September 17–26, 1986|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/newton1986.html}}</ref> Rainfall peaked at {{convert|1.31|in|mm|abbr=on}} southeast of [[Lordsburg, New Mexico|Lordsburg]].<ref name=swrain /> *October 13, 1987 – Moisture from [[1987 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Ramon|Hurricane Ramon]] from the Pacific spread into the state.<ref>{{cite news|author=David Smollar|date=1987-10-13|title=Rainfall Sets Record, Helps Halt Palomar Fire|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref><!--see here - https://www.google.com/search?hl=en&gl=us&tbm=nws&btnmeta_news_search=1&q=tropical+storm+%22new+mexico%22&oq=tropical+storm+%22new+mexico%22&aq=f&aqi=d1d-o1&aql=&gs_sm=e&gs_upl=2661l4604l0l4715l27l14l0l12l12l0l152l284l0.2l2l0#q=tropical+storm+%22new+mexico%22&hl=en&gl=us&sa=X&ei=T5okT43fGsnz0gHyubW1CA&ved=0CBYQpwUoCw&source=lnt&tbs=cdr:1%2Ccd_min%3A6%2F1%2F1987%2Ccd_max%3A11%2F1%2F1987&tbm=nws&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.r_cp.,cf.osb&fp=c97226fe1d6951cb&biw=1600&bih=775 - for bit about New Mexico impact--> *1988 – The Albuquerque National Weather Service reported that the remnants of one of the eastern Pacific tropical cyclones affected the state.<ref name="nwss">{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-07-30|title=September 2004 Weather Highlights for New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2004sepwxsum}}</ref> <!-- Bud? ---> *October 5, 1989 – [[Hurricane Raymond (1989)|Tropical Depression Raymond]] entered the state from Arizona and dissipated in the western portion of the state. The storm produced about {{convert|1|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain across the region,<ref>{{cite web|author=Max Mayfield|date=1989-11-18|title=Hurricane Raymond Preliminary Report Page 2|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/epacific/ep1989/raymond/prenhc/prelim02.gif}}</ref> peaking at {{convert|2.99|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Red River, New Mexico|Red River]].<ref name="swrain"/>
===1990s=== [[File:Ismael 1995 rainfall.gif|right|thumb|Rainfall map for [[Hurricane Ismael]]]] *June 1990 – The remnants of [[1990 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Boris|Hurricane Boris]] from the eastern Pacific dropped {{convert|0.92|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in Wolf Canyon.<ref name="swrain">{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|date=2008-08-10|title=Tropical Cyclone Rainfall for the West|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/tcwest.html|publisher=Weather Prediction Center}}</ref> *June 1990 – Moisture from [[1990 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Douglas|Tropical Storm Douglas]] brought substantial rainfall to the state.<ref>{{cite news|title=1990's active hurricane season had little affect on the U.S.|newspaper=Rocky Mountain News|date=1990-10-23|author=Don Kirkman}}</ref> *October 1, 1990 – In an area already experiencing above-normal rainfall, the remnants of [[Tropical Storm Rachel (1990)|Tropical Storm Rachel]] produced additional precipitation in the state.<ref>{{cite news|agency=United Press International|date=1990-10-01|title=Post Flood Watches through Southwest|newspaper=The Bryan Times|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AjMhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mVcEAAAAIBAJ&dq=tropical%20storm%20rachel&pg=3559%2C608483}}</ref> *August 24, 1992 – [[Hurricane Lester (1992)|Tropical Depression Lester]] moved into the state from Arizona and dissipated near Albuquerque. The highest rainfall total was {{convert|2.17|in|mm|abbr=on}} near Lindrith.<ref name="swrain"/><ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|date=2007-03-06|title=Hurricane Lester - August 19–27, 1992|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/lester1992.html|publisher=Weather Prediction Center}}</ref> The rains caused flash flooding of [[Arroyo (creek)|arroyos]] and a mudslide along [[U.S. Route 180]].<ref>{{cite journal |page=115 |title=Storm Data August 1992 |volume=34 |publisher=National Climatic Data Center |accessdate=2012-03-26 |archivedate=2013-03-20 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FGq4H3t1?url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-EBBF1E19-9CDD-4E41-82D0-F49ECEEDC3EC.pdf |url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-1B5FDE65-0C09-4E89-AC79-CB773C746BC1.pdf |format=PDF |issue=8 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *August 27, 1993 – [[Hurricane Hilary (1993)|Tropical Depression Hilary]] dissipated over northwestern Mexico before producing a surge of moisture that dropped over 25% of the summer rainfall in portions of the state.<ref name="atmos">{{cite journal|author=Kristen L. Corbosiero|author2=Michael Dickinson|author3=Lance Bosart|date=August 2009|title=The Contribution of Eastern North Pacific Tropical Cyclones to the Rainfall Climatology of the Southwest United States|journal=Monthly Weather Review|volume=137|page=2419|accessdate=2012-01-29|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/2009MWR2768.1|format=PDF| doi = 10.1175/2009MWR2768.1|issue=8 |bibcode = 2009MWRv..137.2415C }}</ref> *September 15, 1995 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Ismael]] dropped {{convert|8.53|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in Hobbs,<ref name="swrain"/> with unofficial reports of over {{convert|10|in|mm|abbr=on}}. The intense precipitation flooded many houses and closed several roads. Flooding also washed out three sections of the [[Texas – New Mexico Railroad]] line. Damage was estimated at $250,000 (1995 USD).<ref>{{cite web |author = National Climatic Data Center |year = 1995 |title = Event Report for Hurricane Ismael |accessdate = 2012-01-28 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6FGqD2Qb9?url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-FEDAE4E6-B974-4B3E-A6DF-6A3D4EAD8765.pdf |archivedate = 2013-03-20 |url = http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~217699 |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> *September 14, 1996 – [[Hurricane Fausto (1996)|Hurricane Fausto]] dissipated over Mexico, and its remnant moisture contributed to rainfall and flash floods. Portions of Black River Village reported {{convert|2|ft|m|abbr=on}} of flooding.<ref>{{cite web |author=National Climatic Data Center |year=1996 |title=Event Report for Hurricane Fausto |accessdate=2012-01-28 |archivedate=2013-03-20 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FGqRO5tF?url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-86206CFF-5A6B-49FF-AE0F-305F79346E91.pdf |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~265996 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *September 27, 1997 – As [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] moved through Baja California and Arizona, its outer rainbands produced light rainfall in the northwest portion of the state.<ref>{{cite news|author=John Fleck|newspaper=Albuquerque Journal|date=1997-09-27|title=Hurricane Nora Misses New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://business.highbeam.com/2872/article-1G1-107590890/hurricane-nora-misses-new-mexico}}</ref> *August 11, 1998 – Moisture from [[1998 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Frank|Tropical Storm Frank]] spread from the coast of California through New Mexico.<ref>{{cite news|author=Eric Malnic and Richard Winton|date=1998-08-11|title=The Humidity Hex|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/aug/11/local/me-12049}}</ref> *September 1998 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Isis (1998)|Hurricane Isis]] produced {{convert|1.47|in|mm|abbr=on}} of precipitation at White Signal.<ref name="swrain"/>
===2000s=== [[File:Dolly Remnants 2008.png|thumb|Satellite image of the remnants of [[Hurricane Dolly (2008)|Hurricane Dolly]] entering New Mexico]] *October 11, 2000 – The remnants of [[2000 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Olivia|Tropical Storm Olivia]] from the Pacific dropped heavy rainfall in the northwestern portion of the state.<ref name="ISPE"/> *September 30, 2001 – Moisture from [[Hurricane Juliette (2001)|Tropical Depression Juliette]] spread across the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Miles B. Lawrence|date=2001-09-30|title=Tropical Depression Juliette Discussion Thirty-Seven|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2012-01-28|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2001/dis/ep112001.discus.037.html}}</ref> *September 9, 2002 – Rainfall and thunderstorms spread across the state in association with [[Tropical Storm Fay (2002)|Tropical Storm Fay]] dissipating over Texas.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-08-02|title=September 2002 Weather Highlights for New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2002sepwxsum}}</ref> *July 16, 2003 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Claudette (2003)|Hurricane Claudette]] from the Atlantic produced beneficial rainfall in the southeastern portion of the state.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-08-02|title=July 2003 Weather Highlights for New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2003julwxsum}}</ref> *September 24, 2003 – Rains from [[Hurricane Marty (2003)|Tropical Depression Marty]] in the Sea of Cortez spread across the southwestern United States, including {{convert|1.06|in|mm|abbr=on}} near [[Glenwood, New Mexico|Glenwood]].<ref name="swrain"/><ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|date=2007-01-27|title=Hurricane Marty - September 21–26, 2003|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/marty2003.html|publisher=Weather Prediction Center}}</ref> *October 7, 2003 – A stalled extratropical storm drew moisture from hurricanes [[Hurricane Nora (2003)|Nora]] and [[Hurricane Olaf (2003)|Olaf]] to produce rains in a drought-stricken region, along with flash flooding.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-08-02|title=October 2003 Weather Highlights for New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2003octwxsum}}</ref> *July 3, 2004 – Moisture from [[2004 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Depression Two-E|a tropical depression]] produced a few thunderstorms in the state.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-08-04|title=July 2004 Weather Highlights for New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2004julwxsum}}</ref> *September 21, 2004 – The mid-level remnants of [[Hurricane Javier (2004)|Hurricane Javier]] crossed the northwest portion of the state from the eastern Pacific, dropping {{convert|2.48|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in Albuquerque.<ref name="swrain"/><ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|date=2006-10-31|title=Hurricane Javier - September 18–21, 2004|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/javier2004.html|publisher=Weather Prediction Center}}</ref> *July 22, 2005 – For four days, the remnants of [[Hurricane Emily (2005)|Hurricane Emily]] from the Atlantic Ocean produced thunderstorms across the state.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-07-29|title=July 2005 Weather Highlights for New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2005julwxsum}}</ref> *September 22, 2005 – Thunderstorms were reported across the state in association with the remnants of [[2005 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Max|Hurricane Max]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-07-29|title=September 2005 Weather Highlights for New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2005sepwxsum}}</ref> *October 2, 2005 – Moisture from the remnants of [[Hurricane Otis (2005)|Hurricane Otis]] in the Pacific Ocean produced scattered thunderstorms.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-07-29|title=October 2005 Weather Highlights for New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2005octwxsum}}</ref> *September 2, 2006 – The remnants of [[Hurricane John (2006)|Hurricane John]] from the eastern Pacific produced three days of rainfall in the southern portion of the state. The moisture was amplified by an approaching upper-level trough. [[Ruidoso, New Mexico|Ruidoso]] reported the highest rainfall total with {{convert|5.25|in|mm|abbr=on}}. The precipitation flooded creeks and rivers,<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-07-16|title=September 2006 Weather Highlights for New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2006sepwxsum}}</ref> which entered houses and caused roads to close.<ref>{{cite web |author=National Climatic Data Center |year=2006 |title=Event Report for Hurricane John |accessdate=2013-03-17 |url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=5534695 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FC0CcvS7?url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=5534695 |archivedate=2013-03-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *August 17, 2007 – The outskirts of [[Tropical Storm Erin (2007)|Tropical Depression Erin]], having earlier struck Texas, brushed eastern New Mexico.<ref name="aug07"/> *August 26, 2007 – Moisture from the remnants of [[Hurricane Dean]] moved across the western portion of the state.<ref name="aug07">{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-07-16|title=August 2007 Weather Summary|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2007augwxsum}}</ref> *September 6, 2007 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Henriette (2007)|Hurricane Henriette]] produced rainfall in the southwestern portion of the state.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-07-16|title=September 2007 Weather Summary|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2007sepwxsum}}</ref> The system spawned a [[landspout]] near [[Tyrone, New Mexico|Tyrone]].<ref>{{cite web |author=National Climatic Data Center |year=2007 |title=Event Report for Hurricane Henriette |accessdate=2012-01-27 |url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=61287 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FC03OmBP?url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=61287 |archivedate=2013-03-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *July 26, 2008 – The well-defined circulation of former [[Hurricane Dolly (2008)|Hurricane Dolly]] crossed Texas and eastern Mexico into southeastern New Mexico.<ref name="srh"/> Rainfall totals included a statewide peak of {{convert|8.53|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Sunspot, New Mexico|Sunspot]],<ref name="swrain"/> and more than 6 in (150 mm) Ruidoso. The high totals caused the [[Rio Ruidoso]] and [[Rio Bonito (New Mexico)|Rio Bonito]] to overflow near Rudioso, which resulted in flooding in and around the city. One person died after being swept away by the Rio Ruidoso.<ref name="dncdc"/> Flooding near [[Mescalero, New Mexico|Mescalero]] caused two dams to fail at Mud Canyon. The system also spawned a funnel cloud near [[Las Cruces, New Mexico|Las Cruces]].<ref name="srh">{{cite web|author= Joe Rogas|publisher=El Paso National Weather Service|date=2008-10-09|title=Monsoon Season Brings Severe Thunderstorms and Flood|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/images/epz/swww/swwb2008b.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Across the region, the flooding caused about $25 million in damage after damaging about 500 structures,<ref name="dncdc">{{cite web |author=National Climatic Data Center |year=2008 |title=Event Report for Hurricane Dolly |accessdate=2013-03-17 |url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=107482 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FBzyWlbP?url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=107482 |archivedate=2013-03-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> including 47 destroyed houses.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency|title=New Mexico Storms and Flooding– FEMA-1783-DR - Declared August 14, 2008|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.fema.gov/pdf/news/pda/1783.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> The floods also washed out at least 13 bridges.<ref name="dncdc"/> *September 11, 2008 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Lowell (2008)|Tropical Storm Lowell]] from the eastern Pacific produced flash flooding near [[Hobbs, New Mexico|Hobbs]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-07-20|title=September 2008 Weather Summary|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2008sepwxsum}}</ref> Remnant moisture also contributed to the development of an EF0 tornado, which touched down near [[Vaughn, New Mexico|Vaughn]].<ref>{{cite journal |page=114 |title=Storm Data September 2008 |volume=50 |publisher=National Climatic Data Center |accessdate=2013-01-04 |url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-2122C9F2-75A1-4D97-98C5-3A0CBB44FA8B.pdf |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FBzrZ2XQ?url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-2122C9F2-75A1-4D97-98C5-3A0CBB44FA8B.pdf |archivedate=2013-03-17 |issue=9 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *October 11, 2008 – After making landfall in western Mexico, [[Hurricane Norbert (2008)|Hurricane Norbert]] produced rainfall and thunderstorms across New Mexico after combining with a powerful storm moving through the [[Great Basin]]. The rainfall reached {{convert|1.5|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[House, New Mexico|House]], and the thunderstorms caused tree damage and dropped large hail.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|date=2010-07-16|title=October 11, 2008: Severe Weather Across Central and Northern New Mexico|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2008octsigevents}}</ref> *September 2, 2009 – While striking Baja California, [[Hurricane Jimena (2009)|Hurricane Jimena]] spread rainfall into portions of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Zack Guido|date=2009-11-23|title=The 2009 southwest monsoon: El Niño's heavy hand|accessdate=2012-01-27|publisher=University of Arizona|url=http://www.climas.arizona.edu/feature-articles/november-2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100618173306/http://www.climas.arizona.edu/feature-articles/november-2009|archivedate=2010-06-18|df=}}</ref>
===2010s=== *July 2010 – Dissipating [[Hurricane Alex (2010)|Hurricane Alex]] dropped over 3 in (75 mm) of rainfall in the southeast portion of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|date=2010-08-28|title=Hurricane Alex - June 29 – July 6, 2010|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/alex2010.html}}</ref> *September 22, 2010 – Moisture from the remnants of [[Tropical Storm Georgette (2010)|Tropical Storm Georgette]] in the eastern Pacific combined with an approaching upper-level [[trough (meteorology)|trough]] to produce heavy rainfall and thunderstorms across the state. A total of {{convert|6.42|in|mm|abbr=on}} was reported in [[Gladstone, New Mexico|Gladstone]].<ref>{{cite web|date=2010-12-31|title=A Recipe for Heavy Rain - September 22, 2010|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2010sepsigevents}}</ref> The rains caused flooding that killed a person along the Rio Grande near [[Carnuel, New Mexico|Carnuel]].<ref>{{cite web |author=National Climatic Data Center |year=2010 |title=Event Report for Tropical Storm Georgette |accessdate=2013-03-17 |url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=252947 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FBzlhkEG?url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/eventdetails.jsp?id=252947 |archivedate=2013-03-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *September 28, 2012 – The remnants of [[2012 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Miriam|Hurricane Miriam]] dropped rainfall in the southeastern portion of the state.<ref>{{cite web|date=2012-10-04|title=September 2012 Weather Highlights|publisher=Albuquerque, New Mexico National Weather Service|accessdate=2013-01-02|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/abq/?n=climonhigh2012sepwxsum}}</ref> *September 17, 2014 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Norbert (2014)|Hurricane Norbert]] caused significant damage to [[List of highways numbered 152|New Mexico Highway 152]]. Due to the severity of damage, the [[New Mexico Department of Transportation]] closed the road indefinitely and stated it could be more than a month until it was re-opened.<ref>{{cite web|author=Susan Dunlap |publisher=Silver City Sun-News |location=Silver City, New Mexico |date=September 17, 2014 |accessdate=June 3, 2015 |title=Highway 152 closed indefinitely due to recent storm damage |url=http://www.scsun-news.com/silver_city-news/ci_26555964 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924035225/http://www.scsun-news.com/silver_city-news/ci_26555964 |archivedate=September 24, 2014 |df= }}</ref> *September 18–20, 2014 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Odile (2014)|Hurricane Odile]] brought heavy rainfall to southwestern New Mexico. Floods from the remnants killed one oil field worker.<ref name=Disc32>{{cite web|author1=Kong, Kwan-Yin|title=Remnants of Odile Advisory Number 32|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/tropical_advisories.php?storm=ODILE&adnum=32&dt=2014091803&status=remnants|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=2015-06-03|location=College Park, Maryland|date=2014-09-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/breaking-body-of-missing-texas/34308556|title=Sheriff's Deputy, Oil Field Worker Die in Odile Flooding|date=September 20, 2014|accessdate=June 3, 2015}}</ref> *June 5, 2015 – The remnants of [[2015 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Andres|Hurricane Andres]] brought rain to northern New Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Pydynowski, Kristina|url=http://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/remnants-of-andres-to-enhance/48130284|title=Remnants of Andres to Enhance Thunderstorms From Arizona to Wyoming|date=2015-06-06|publisher=AccuWeather|accessdate=2015-07-11}}</ref> *September 5, 2015 – Moisture drawn northeast from [[2015 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Kevin|Tropical Storm Kevin]] brought scattered storms to the [[Four Corners]] region.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Pydynowski, Kristina|url=http://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/tropical-storm-kevin-to-increa/52165452|title=Tropical Storm Kevin to Increase Thunderstorms in Mexico, US Four Corners|date=2015-09-05|publisher=AccuWeather|accessdate=2015-09-06}}</ref>{{clear}} *September 7, 2016 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Newton (2016)|Hurricane Newton]] brought very heavy rains to western and central New Mexico.

'''Chainsaw carving competitions''' are competitive events held all over the world where contestants display their skills in the act of [[chainsaw carving]].
==Australia== *Australian Chainsaw Carving Championship, [[Melbourne]]<ref>{{citation|newspaper=Daily Mail|title=The world's loudest art form: Chainsaw sculptors turn giant chunks of wood into lyrebirds, seahorses and life-size swagmen|author=Ryan Lipman|date=24 May 2014|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2638071/Worlds-best-chainsaw-sculptors-turn-wood-art.html}}</ref>
==Canada== *Chetwynd (International) Chainsaw Carving Competition (Championship), [[Chetwynd, British Columbia]]<ref>{{citation|title=Chetwynd chainsaw carving sale has community buzzing: Mayor says it was tough to part with sculptures, but public collection getting too big|date=February 22, 2016|publisher=CBC|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/chetwynd-chainsaw-carving-sale-1.3459305}}</ref> held annually since 2005<ref>{{citation|title=Chainsaw Carvings – history|publisher=Chetwynd Visitor Centre/District of Chetwynd, British Columbia|work=Official website|url=http://www.gochetwynd.com/visitors/chainsaw-carvings|accessdate=2016-09-01}}</ref> *Brigade Days/Hope Chainsaw Carving Competition, [[Hope, British Columbia]], biannually<ref>{{citation|title=Arts and Culture: Chainsaw Carving Competition|publisher=Hope, British Columbia|work=Official website|year=2015|url=http://hopebc.ca/community/arts-and-culture/|accessdate=2016-09-01}}</ref> *Prince George Chain Saw Carving Competition, [[Prince George, British Columbia]]
==Japan== *[[Tōei, Aichi]], since 2001<ref>{{citation|title=The 16th Chainsaw Art Competition in Toei|newspaper=Japan Times|date=May 24, 2016|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/events/2016/05/24/art-guide/sculpture-art-guide/the-16th-chainsaw-art-competition-in-toei/}}</ref>
==United Kingdom== *Carve Carrbridge, [[Carrbridge]], Scotland, held annually since 2003<ref>{{citation|title=Wood work: Images from Carrbridge's chainsaw contest|publisher=BBC|date=1 September 2014|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-29010701}}</ref> *English Open Chainsaw Carving Competition, [[Tatton Park]], Cheshire, England, since 2005<ref>{{citation|title=Tatton Park hosts English Open Chainsaw Carving Competition|date=August 8, 2009|newspaper=Messenger Newspapers (UK)|publisher=[[Newsquest ]]|url=http://www.messengernewspapers.co.uk/news/4533578.Chainsaws_at_the_ready/}}</ref>
==United States== [[File:Ocean Shores chainsaws.jpg|thumb|Tools of the trade at a chainsaw carving demonstration and competition held in [[Ocean Shores, Washington]]]] ===Alaska=== *Seldovia Craft Invitational Chainsaw Competition, [[Seldovia, Alaska]], annually since 2006<ref>{{citation|title=Chips to fly this weekend in chainsaw competition|author=Jenny Chissus|newspaper=Homer News|location=Homer, Alaska|date=August 28, 2013|url=http://homernews.com/homer-news/local-news/2013-08-28/chips-to-fly-this-weekend-in-chainsaw-competition}}</ref>
===Montana=== *Kootenai Country Montana International Chainsaw Carving Championship, [[Libby, Montana]], <ref>{{citation|title=Chainsaw carving championship returns to Libby|newspaper=The Montanian|date=January 23, 2018|url=http://montanian.com/top-stories/chainsaw-carving-championship-returns-to-libby/}}</ref>
===Oregon=== *Reedsport Chainsaw Carving Competition/Oregon Divisional Chainsaw Sculpting Championship, [[Reedsport, Oregon]],<ref>{{citation|title=Chainsaw Sculpting Championships |work=Oregon Coast|date=May 2008|url=http://www.oregoncoastmagazine.com/oregon_coast_chainsaw_championships.php}}</ref> held annually since 2000<ref>{{citation|title=Carving creates a stir in chainsaw capital|newspaper=The Umpqua Post|author=Steve Lindsley |date=June 24, 2015|url=http://theworldlink.com/reedsport/news/carving-creates-a-stir-in-chainsaw-capital/article_3607fd84-a37a-59ba-99d2-83cc23cb7ee0.html}}</ref>
===Pennsylvania=== *Chainsaw Carvers Rendezvous, [[Ridgway, Pennsylvania]], held annually since 2000<ref>{{citation|title=Let the sawdust fly — Chainsaw Rendezvous takes over Ridgway |author=Bob Batz Jr.|newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|date=March 5, 2016|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/life/lifestyle/2016/03/05/Let-the-sawdust-fly-Chainsaw-Rendezvous-takes-over-Ridgway/stories/201603050001}}</ref>
===Washington=== *Burning Bear, [[Ocean City, Washington]]<ref>{{citation|title=Chainsaw artist carves out creations|date=June 12, 2009|author1=Jason Smathers|author2=Judy Halone|newspaper=Bonney Lake Courier-Herald|url=http://www.blscourierherald.com/business/44773812.html}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=North Beach chainsaw artist found his calling|author=Angelo Bruscas|date=June 24, 2015|newspaper=The North Coast News|location=Ocean Shores, Washington|url=http://northcoastnews.com/livinglifestyles/north-beach-chainsaw-artist-found-his-calling.html}}</ref> *Sedro Woolley Logger-Rodeo (Loggerodeo), [[Sedro Woolley, Washington]], since before 1999<ref>{{citation|title=Inventing Work in a Rural Community: Exploring the Social, Historical and Cultural Dimensions of School-to-work and Work-to-work Transitions|first=Mark R.|last=Jury|publisher=University of California, Berkeley|year=1999|p=108|url=https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=Rw1NAQAAMAAJ}}</ref> *Sequim Irrigation Fest, [[Sequim, Washington]], featuring Logging Show since 1989<ref>{{citation|title=Sequim Irrigation Fest to showcase 121 years |newspaper=Sequim Gazette|date=May 11, 2016|url=http://www.sequimgazette.com/news/379025241.html}}</ref> *Sand and Sawdust, [[Ocean Shores, Washington]]<ref>{{citation|title=On the road: Sand and Sawdust Festival|date=June 15, 2016|newspaper=The News Tribune|location=Tacoma, Washington|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/outdoors/article83610057.html}}</ref> *Texas Chainsaw Pumpkin Carving Contest, [[Fremont, Seattle|Fremont]] [[Oktoberfest celebrations|Oktoberfest]] in Seattle since before 2005, draws 30,000 spectators<ref>{{citation|title=Nothing says fall like the whir of chainsaws|author=Madeline McKenzie|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=September 22, 2005|url=http://old.seattletimes.com/html/outdoors/2002511225_nwwfestival22.html}}</ref>
===Wisconsin=== *US Open Chainsaw Sculpture Championship, [[Eau Claire, Wisconsin]]<ref>{{citation|title=The best in chainsaw carving flock to Carson Park for U.S. Open|publisher=[[WEAU]] News| author=Matt Hoffman |date=August 9, 2012|url=http://www.weau.com/home/headlines/The-best-in-chainsaw-carving-flock-to-Carson-Park-for-US-Open-165642266.html}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Chainsaw carving|*]] [[Category:Lumberjack sports|*]] [[Category:Forestry-related lists|Chainsaw]]

page.title: List of dates predicted for apocalyptic events

revision.text:
{{Dynamic list}} [[File:Das Jüngste Gericht (Memling).jpg|thumb|300px|right|''[[The Last Judgment (Memling)|The Last Judgment]]'' by painter [[Hans Memling]]. In Christian belief, the [[Last Judgement]] is an apocalyptic event where God makes a final judgement of all people on Earth.|alt=A three paneled colour painting. The centre panel shows Jesus sitting in judgment on the world, while St Michael is weighing souls. On the left hand panel, the saved are being guided into heaven, while on the right-hand panel, the damned are being dragged to hell]] Predictions of [[apocalypse|apocalyptic events]] that would result in the [[Human extinction|extinction of humanity]], a [[Global catastrophic risk|collapse of civilization]], or the destruction of the planet have been made since at least the beginning of the [[Common Era]].{{cite journal |last=Cole-Turner |first=Ronald |date=2012 |title=The singularity and the rapture: Transhumanist and popular Christian views of the future |journal=[[Zygon (journal)|Zygon]] |volume=47 |issue=4 |pages=777–796 }} Most predictions are related to [[Abrahamic religions]], often standing for or similar to the [[eschatological]] events described in their scriptures. Christian predictions typically refer to events like the [[Rapture]], [[Great Tribulation]], [[Last Judgment]], and the [[Second Coming of Christ]]. End-time events are usually predicted to occur within the lifetime of the person making the prediction, and are usually made using the Bible, and in particular the [[New Testament]], as either the primary or exclusive source for the predictions. Often this takes the form of mathematical calculations, such as trying to calculate the point where it will have been [[Year 6000|6000 years]] since the supposed creation of the Earth by the [[God in Abrahamic religions|Abrahamic God]],{{sfn|Aveni|2016|page=7}} which according to the [[Talmud]] marks the deadline for the [[Messiah]] to appear. Predictions of the end from [[natural disaster|natural events]] have also been theorised by various scientists and scientific groups. While these predictions are generally accepted as plausible within the scientific community, the events and phenomena are not expected to occur for hundreds of thousands or even billions of years from now. Little research has been done into why people make apocalyptic predictions. Historically, it has been done for reasons such as diverting attention from actual crises like poverty and war, pushing political agendas, and promoting hatred of certain groups; [[antisemitism]] was a popular theme of Christian apocalyptic predictions in medieval times,{{cite web |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/people-have-always-been-obsessed-end-world-180956525/ |title=People Have Always Been Obsessed with the End of the World |last=Fessensden |first=Marissa |date=September 8, 2015 |work=[[Smithsonian (magazine)|Smithsonian]] |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180425054533/https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/people-have-always-been-obsessed-end-world-180956525/ |archivedate=April 25, 2018 |deadurl=no}} while French and [[Lutheran]] depictions of the apocalypse were known to feature English and Catholic antagonists respectively.{{cite web |url=https://theconversation.com/apocalypse-now-our-incessant-desire-to-picture-the-end-of-the-world-46104 |title=Apocalypse now: our incessant desire to picture the end of the world |last= |first= |date=August 25, 2015 |work=[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180516234124/https://theconversation.com/apocalypse-now-our-incessant-desire-to-picture-the-end-of-the-world-46104 |archivedate=May 16, 2018 |deadurl=no}} According to psychologists, possible explanations for why people believe in modern apocalyptic predictions include mentally reducing the actual danger in the world to a single and definable source, an innate human fascination with fear, personality traits of paranoia and powerlessness and a modern romanticism involved with end-times due to its portrayal in contemporary fiction.{{cite web |url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/psychology-reveals-the-comforts-of-the-apocalypse/ |title=Psychology Reveals the Comforts of the Apocalypse |last=Yuhas |first=Daisy |date=December 18, 2012 |work=[[Scientific American]] |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180425053659/https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/psychology-reveals-the-comforts-of-the-apocalypse/ |archivedate=April 25, 2018 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/doomsday-postpone-again-heres-why-were-obsessed-end-world-according-psychology-670860 |title=Doomsday Is Postponed Again: Here's Why We’re All So Obsessed With The End Of World, According to Psychology |last=Dovey |first=Dana |date=September 26, 2017 |work=[[Newsweek]] |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180425053733/http://www.newsweek.com/doomsday-postpone-again-heres-why-were-obsessed-end-world-according-psychology-670860 |archivedate=April 25, 2018 |deadurl=no}} The prevalence of Abrahamic religions throughout modern history is said to have created a culture which encourages the embracement of a future that will be drastically different from the present.{{sfn|Aveni|2016|page=xii}} Such a culture is credited with the rise in popularity of predictions that are more secular in nature, such as the [[2012 phenomenon]], while maintaining the centuries-old theme that a powerful force will bring the end of humanity.{{sfn|Aveni|2016|page=xii}} Polls conducted in 2012 across 20 countries found over 14% of people believe the world will end in their lifetime, with percentages ranging from 6% of people in France to 22% in the US and Turkey. Belief in the apocalypse is most prevalent in people with lower rates of education, lower household incomes, and those under the age of 35.{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-05-02/news/ct-talk-end-of-the-world-poll-0502-20120502_1_mayan-calendar-new-poll-mayan-prophecy |title=Apocalypse now: Poll shows 1 in 7 thinks end of world is near |date=May 2, 2012 |work=[[The Chicago Tribune]] |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180425025021/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-05-02/news/ct-talk-end-of-the-world-poll-0502-20120502_1_mayan-calendar-new-poll-mayan-prophecy |archivedate=April 25, 2018 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=https://www.ipsos.com/en-us/one-seven-14-global-citizens-believe-end-world-coming-their-lifetime |title=One in Seven (14%) Global Citizens Believe End of the World is Coming in Their Lifetime |date=May 1, 2012 |work=[[Ipsos]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180425025212/https://www.ipsos.com/en-us/one-seven-14-global-citizens-believe-end-world-coming-their-lifetime |archivedate=April 25, 2018 |deadurl=no}} In the UK in 2015, 23% of the general public believed the apocalypse was likely to occur in their lifetime, compared to 10% of experts from the [[Global Challenges Foundation]]. The general public believed the likeliest cause would be [[nuclear war]], while experts thought it would be [[Existential risk from artificial general intelligence|artificial intelligence]]. Only 3% of Britons thought the end would be caused by the Last Judgement, compared to 16% of Americans. Between one and three percent of people from both countries thought the apocalypse would be caused by [[zombies]] or [[alien invasion]].{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2015/03/13/do-experts-and-the-public-think-differently-about-the-apocalypse/?noredirect=on |title=Do experts and the public think differently about the apocalypse? |last=Drezner |first=Daniel W. |date=March 13, 2015 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180625050443/https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2015/03/13/do-experts-and-the-public-think-differently-about-the-apocalypse/?noredirect=on |archivedate=June 25, 2018 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=https://d25d2506sfb94s.cloudfront.net/cumulus_uploads/document/c0zsgscxwo/InternalResults_150309_apocalyptic_disaster_Website.pdf |title=YouGov Survey Result |date=March 9, 2015 |work=[[YouGov]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150330082256/https://d25d2506sfb94s.cloudfront.net/cumulus_uploads/document/c0zsgscxwo/InternalResults_150309_apocalyptic_disaster_Website.pdf |archivedate=March 30, 2015 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=https://yougov.co.uk/news/2015/03/10/apocalypse/ |title=UKIP voters most likely to think the apocalypse is coming |last=Dahlgreen |first=Will |date=March 10, 2015 |work=[[YouGov]] }} ==Eschatological predictions== This section lists eschatological predictions, mostly by religious individuals or groups. Most predictions are related to [[Abrahamic religions]], with numerous predictions standing for the [[eschatological]] events described in their scriptures. Christian predictions typically refer to events like the [[Rapture]], [[Great Tribulation]], [[Last Judgment]], and the [[Second Coming of Christ]]. ===Past predictions=== {|class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col" width=|Date (CE) ! scope="col" width=|Claimant(s) ! scope="col" |Description ! scope="col" |{{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- |66–70 |[[Simon bar Giora]], [[Essenes|Jewish Essenes]] |The Jewish Essene sect of ascetics saw the Jewish uprising against the Romans in 66–70 in Judea as the final end-time battle which would bring about the arrival of the [[Messiah]]. By the authority of Simon, coins were minted declaring the redemption of Israel. |align=center|{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/apocalypse/etc/script.html|title=Apocalypse|author1=William Cran|author2=Ben Loeterman|date=November 22, 1998|work=[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130113034514/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/apocalypse/etc/script.html|archivedate=January 13, 2013|deadurl=no|df=}}
{{cite journal |last1=Evans |first1=Craig A. |last2= |first2= |date=2006 |title=Messianic Hopes and Messianic Figures in Late Antiquity |journal=Journal of Greco-Roman Christianity and Judaism |volume=3 |issue= |pages=9–40 |url= |doi= }} |- |365 |[[Hilary of Poitiers]] |This early French bishop announced the end of the world would happen during this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Boyett|2005|page=30}} |- |375–400 |[[Martin of Tours]] |This French bishop stated that the world would end before 400 AD, writing, "There is no doubt that the Antichrist has already been born. Firmly established already in his early years, he will, after reaching maturity, achieve supreme power." |align=center|{{sfn|Lazarus|2008|page=237}}
{{sfn|Abanes|1998|page=119}} |- |500 |[[Hippolytus of Rome]], [[Sextus Julius Africanus]], [[Irenaeus]] |All three predicted Jesus would return in this year, with one of the predictions being based on the dimensions of [[Noah's Ark]]. |align=center|{{sfn|Boyett|2005|page=31}}
{{sfn|Strandberg|2003|page=35}} |- |6 Apr 793 |[[Beatus of Liébana]] |This Spanish monk prophesied the Second Coming of Christ and the end of the world on that day in front of a large crowd of people. |align=center|{{sfn|Boyett|2005|page=31}} |- |800 |[[Sextus Julius Africanus]] |This Christian historian revised his prediction from the year 500 to 800. |align=center|{{sfn|Kyle|1998|page=37}} |- |799–806 |[[Gregory of Tours]] |This French bishop calculated the end would occur between 799 and 806. |align=center|{{sfn|Weber|1999|page=48}} |- |847 |[[Thiota]] |This Christian declared in 847 that the world would end that year, though later confessed the prediction was fraudulent and was publicly flogged. |align=center|{{sfn|Abanes|1998|page=337}}
{{sfn|Palmer|2014|page=161}} |- |992–995 |Various Christians |[[Good Friday]] coincided with the [[Feast of the Annunciation]]; this had long been believed to be the event that would bring forth the Antichrist, and thus the end-times, within three years. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|page=236}} |- |1 Jan 1000 |[[Pope Sylvester II]] |Various Christian clerics predicted this date as the [[Millennialism|Millennium]], including [[Pope Sylvester II]]. Riots occurred in Europe and pilgrims headed east to Jerusalem. |align=center|{{sfn|Boyett|2005|page=32}}
{{sfn|Strandberg|2003|pages=35–36}} |- |1033 |Various Christians |Following the failure of the 1 January 1000, prediction, some theorists proposed that the end would occur 1000 years after Jesus' death, instead of his birth. |align=center|{{sfn|Boyett|2005|page=31}}
{{sfn|Strandberg|2003|page=36}} |- |1200–1260 |[[Joachim of Fiore]] |This Italian mystic determined that the Millennium would begin between 1200 and 1260. |align=center|{{sfn|Kyle|1998|page=48}} |- |1284 |[[Pope Innocent III]] |Pope Innocent III (died 1216) predicted that the world would end [[Number of the Beast|666]] years after the rise of Islam. |align=center|{{sfn|Lazarus|2008|page=237}} |- |1290
1335 |[[Joachimites]] |After his 1260 prediction failed, the followers of Joachim of Fiore rescheduled the end of the world to 1290 and then again to 1335. |align=center|{{sfn|McIver|1999|page=58}} |- |1346–1351 |Various Europeans |The [[Black Death]] spreading across Europe was interpreted by many as the sign of the end of times. |align=center|{{sfn|Boyett|2005|page=33}}
{{sfn|Byrne|2008|page=67}} |- |1368–1370 |[[Jean de Roquetaillade]] |This French [[alchemist]] predicted the Antichrist was to come in 1366 and the Millennium would begin either in 1368 or 1370. |align=center|{{sfn|Weber|1999|page=55}} |- |1378 |[[Arnaldus de Villa Nova]] |This [[Joachite]] wrote that the Antichrist was to come during this year. |align=center|{{sfn|McIver|1999|page=62}} |- |1504 |[[Sandro Botticelli]] |This painter believed he was living during the Tribulation, and that the Millennium would begin in three and a half years from 1500. He wrote into his painting ''[[The Mystical Nativity]]'' that the Devil was loose and would soon be chained. |align=center|{{sfn|Weber|1999|page=60}}
{{sfn|Durant|1953|page=139}} |- |1 Feb 1524 |London astrologers |A group of astrologers in London predicted the world would end by a flood starting in London, based on calculations made the previous June. Twenty thousand Londoners left their homes and headed for higher ground in anticipation. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|pages=236–237}}
{{sfn|Ashe|2001|page=79}} |- |20 Feb 1524 |[[Johannes Stöffler]] |A planetary alignment in [[Pisces (astrology)|Pisces]] was seen by this astrologer as a sign of the Millennium. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|pages=236–237}} |- |1524–1526 |[[Thomas Müntzer]] |1525 would mark the beginning of the Millennium, according to this [[Anabaptism|Anabaptist]]. His followers were killed by cannon fire in an uneven battle with government troops. He died under torture and was beheaded. |align=center|{{sfn|Strandberg|2003|page=36}}
{{sfn|Gould|1998|page=48}} |- |27 May 1528 |[[Hans Hut]] |This German Anabaptist predicted the end would occur on this date. |align=center|{{sfn|Weber|1999|page=67}} |- |1528 |[[Johannes Stöffler]] |A revised date from Stöffler after his 1524 prediction failed to come true. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|page=238}} |- |19 Oct 1533 |[[Michael Stifel]] |This mathematician calculated that Judgement Day would begin at 8:00 am on this day. |align=center|{{sfn|McIver|1999|page=88}} |- |1533 |[[Melchior Hoffman]] |This Anabaptist prophet predicted Christ's Second Coming to take place this year in [[Strasbourg]]. He claimed that [[144,000]] people would be saved, while the rest of the world would be consumed by fire. |align=center|{{sfn|Kyle|1998|page=59}} |- |5 Apr 1534 |[[Jan Matthys]] |During the [[Münster rebellion]], this Anabaptist leader declared that the apocalypse would take place on this day. When the day came he led a failed attack against [[Franz von Waldeck]] and was decapitated. |align=center|{{sfn|Abanes|1998|page=338}} |- |1555 |[[Pierre d'Ailly]] |Around 1400, this French theologian wrote that 6845 years of human history had already passed, and the end of the world would be in the 7000th year. |align=center|{{sfn|McIver|1999|page=72}} |- |1585 |[[Michael Servetus]] |In his book ''The Restoration of Christianity'', the Spanish born reformer claimed that the Devil's reign in this world had started in 325 AD, at the [[First Council of Nicea|Council of Nicea]], and would last for 1260 years, thus ending in 1585. |align=center|{{sfn|Servetus|1553}} |- |1588 |[[Regiomontanus]] |This mathematician and astronomer predicted the end of the world during this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|page=239}} |- |1600 |[[Martin Luther]] |Luther, a German priest and professor of theology, predicted the end of the world would occur no later than 1600. |align=center|{{sfn|Weber|1999|page=66}} |- |1 Feb 1624 |London astrologers |The same astrologers who predicted the deluge of 1 February 1524, recalculated the date to 100 years later after their first prophecy failed. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|pages=236–237}}
{{sfn|Ashe|2001|page=79}} |- |1648 |[[Sabbatai Zevi]] |Using the [[kabbalah]], this rabbi from Turkey proclaimed that the Messiah would come during that year. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|page=239}} |- |1651 |Unknown author from [[Lübeck]], [[Germany]] |The apocalypse maps tell of an Antichrist, the rise of Islam and other events following Judgement Day that was predicted to occur in 1651. |align=center|{{cite web |last=Martin |first=Sean |url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/science/670133/Apocalyptic-medieval-map-of-Hell-predicted-Islam-will-conquer-Europe |title=Apocalyptic medieval map of Hell predicted Islam will conquer Europe |work=[[Daily Express]] |date=May 14, 2016 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170806091947/http://www.express.co.uk/news/science/670133/Apocalyptic-medieval-map-of-Hell-predicted-Islam-will-conquer-Europe |archivedate=August 6, 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }}
{{cite web |url=http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2016/05/11/these-15th-century-maps-show-how-the-apocalypse-will-go-down/ |title=These 15th-Century Maps Show How the Apocalypse Will Go Down |date=November 15, 2016 |work=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20160514090450/http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2016/05/11/these-15th-century-maps-show-how-the-apocalypse-will-go-down/ |archivedate=May 14, 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- |1654 |[[Helisaeus Roeslin]] |This physician made a prediction that the world would end this year based on a [[nova]] that occurred in 1572. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|page=240}} |- |1656 |[[Christopher Columbus]] |In his ''[[Book of Prophecies]]'' (1501), Columbus predicted that the world would end during this year. |align=center|{{sfn|McGovern|1992|page=17}}
{{sfn|Stackhouse|1997|page=50}} |- |1655–1657 |[[Fifth Monarchists]] |This group of radical Christians predicted that the final apocalyptic battle and the destruction of the Antichrist were to take place between 1655 and 1657. |align=center|{{sfn|Kyle|1998|page=67}} |- |1658 |[[Christopher Columbus]] |Columbus claimed that the world was created in 5343 BCE, and would last 7000 years. Assuming no year zero, that means the end would come in 1658. |align=center|{{sfn|McIver|1999|page=77}} |- |1660 |[[Joseph Mede]] |Mede claimed that the Antichrist had appeared in 456, and the end would come in 1660. |align=center|{{sfn|McIver|1999|page=147}} |- |rowspan="2"|1666 |[[Sabbatai Zevi]] |Following his failed prediction of 1648, Zevi recalculated the end of the Earth for this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|page=239}} |- |[[Fifth Monarchists]] |The presence of [[Number of the Beast|666]] in the date, the death of 100,000 Londoners to [[bubonic plague]], and the [[Great Fire of London]] led to superstitious fears of the end of the world from some Christians. |align=center|{{sfn|Strandberg|2003|pages=36–37}}
{{sfn|Schwartz|1995|page=87}} |- |1673 |[[William Aspinwall]] |This [[Fifth Monarchists|Fifth Monarchist]] claimed the Millennium would begin by this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Abanes|1998|page=209}} |- |1688 |[[John Napier]] |This mathematician calculated the end of the world would be this year based on calculations from the [[Book of Revelation]]. |align=center|{{sfn|Weber|1999|page=92}} |- |1689 |[[Pierre Jurieu]] |This prophet predicted that Judgement Day would occur this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Kyle|1998|page=70}} |- |rowspan="3"|1694 |[[John Mason (poet)|John Mason]] |This Anglican priest predicted the Millennium would begin by this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Kyle|1998|page=72}} |- |[[Johann Heinrich Alsted]] |This [[Calvinist]] minister predicted the Millennium would begin by this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Kyle|1998|page=66}} |- |[[Johann Jacob Zimmermann]] |Believed that Jesus would return and the world would end this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Cohen|1999|pages=19–20}} |- |1697 |[[Cotton Mather]] |This Puritan minister predicted the world would end this year. After the prediction failed, he revised the date of the end two more times. |align=center|{{sfn|Abanes|1998|page=338}} |- |rowspan="2"|1700 |[[John Napier]] |Following his 1688 prediction, Napier recalculated his end of the world prediction to 1700 in ''A Plaine Discovery'', a book published in 1593. |align=center|{{cite book |last1=Rice |first1=Brian |last2=González-Velasco |first2=Enrique |align=center|{{sfn|Abanes|1998|page=338}} |- |5 Apr 1719 |[[Jacob Bernoulli]] |This mathematician predicted a comet would destroy the Earth on this day. |align=center|{{sfn|Randi|1993|page=240}} |- |1700–1734 |[[Nicholas of Cusa]] |This cardinal predicted the end would occur between 1700 and 1734. |align=center|{{sfn|McIver|1999|page=73}} |- |16 Oct 1736 |[[William Whiston]] |This theologian predicted a comet colliding with the Earth this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Hegel|2014|page=246}} |- |1736 |[[Cotton Mather]] |Mather's third and final prediction for the end of the world. |align=center|{{sfn|Abanes|1998|page=338}} |- |1757 |[[Emanuel Swedenborg]] |Swedenborg, a former Lutheran, claimed that the [[Last Judgement]] occurred in the spiritual world this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Swedenborg|1758}}
{{sfn|Spinks|2006|page=114}} |- |19 May 1780 |[[Connecticut General Assembly]] members, [[New Englanders]] |The sky turning dark during the day was [[New England's Dark Day|interpreted as a sign of the end times]]. Eventually it was discovered to be a hoax. The owner, [[Mary Bateman]], had written on the eggs in a corrosive ink so as to etch the eggs, and reinserted the eggs back into the hen's [[oviduct]]. |align=center|{{sfn|Strandberg|2003|page=37}}
{{cite web |url=https://www.livescience.com/7926-10-failed-doomsday-predictions.html |title=10 Failed Doomsday Predictions |last=Radford |first=Benjamin |date=November 4, 2009 |work=[[Live Science]] |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170806102918/https://www.livescience.com/7926-10-failed-doomsday-predictions.html |archivedate=August 6, 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }} |- |19 Oct 1814 |[[Joanna Southcott]] |This 64-year-old self-described prophet claimed she was pregnant with the Christ child, and that he would be born on October 19, 1814. He wrote that Revelation 12:14 referred to 1058 to 1836, "when Christ should come". |align=center|{{sfn|Strandberg|2003|page=37}}

31 Dec 1843 |[[Millerism|Millerites]] |Although it was not officially endorsed by their leadership, many Millerites expected the Second Coming to occur on April 28 or at the end of 1843. |align=center|{{sfn|Festinger|1956|page=16}} |- |1843 |[[Harriet Livermore]] |The first of two years this preacher predicted the world would end. |align=center|{{sfn|McIver|1999|page=699}} |- |21 Mar 1844 |[[William Miller (preacher)|William Miller]] |Miller, a Baptist preacher, predicted Christ would return on this day. |align=center|{{sfn|Festinger|1956|page=17}} |- |22 Oct 1844 |[[Millerism|Millerites]] |After Christ did not return on 21 March 1844, the Millerites then revised William Miller's prediction to 22 October that year, claiming to have miscalculated Scripture. {{sfn|Strandberg|2003|page=38}} |- |7 Aug 1847 |[[George Rapp]] |Rapp, the founder of the [[Harmony Society]], preached that Jesus would return in his lifetime, even as he lay dying on August 7, 1847. |align=center|{{sfn|Cohen|1999|page=23}} |- |1847 |[[Harriet Livermore]] |The second prediction of the end of the world from this preacher. |align=center|{{sfn|McIver|1999|page=699}} |- |rowspan="2"|1862 |[[John Cumming (clergyman)|John Cumming]] |This Scottish clergyman stated it was 6000 years since creation in 1862, and that the world would end. |align=center|{{sfn|Abanes|1998|page=283}} |- |[[Church of the Firstborn (Morrisite)|Joseph Morris]] |Originally an English convert to [[Mormonism]], Morris had revelations to gather his followers and wait for the [[Second Coming]], through successive prophesied days. |align=center|{{cite journal |last1=Howard |first1=G.M. |year=1976 |title=Men, Motives, and Misunderstandings: A New Look at the Morrisite War of 1862 |journal=Utah Historical Quarterly |volume=44 |issue=2}} |- |1863 |[[John Wroe]] |The founder of the [[Christian Israelite Church]] calculated that the Millennium would begin this year. |align=center|{{sfn|Skinner|1994|page=109}} |- |1873 |[[Jonas Wendell]] |In 1870, Wendell published his views in the booklet entitled ''The Present Truth, or Meat in Due Season'' concluding that the [[Second Advent]] was sure to occur in 1873. |align=center|{{sfn|Wendell|1870}} |- |1874 |[[Charles Taze Russell]] |This Christian minister predicted the return of Jesus to occur in 1874, and after this date reinterpreted the prediction to say that Jesus had indeed returned in invisible form. |align=center|{{sfn|Neusner|2009|page=242}}
{{sfn|Stone|2000|page=56}} |- |1881 |[[Mother Shipton]] (attrib.) |This 15th-century prophet was quoted as saying "The world to an end shall come, In eighteen hundred and eighty one" in a book published in 1862.
